headline: It's what you make of it
pros: Good salary and benefits, great people, great experience in 'big business' with opportunities to develop professional and consulting skills, collaborating with a variety of clients in a variety of industries, collaborating with colleagues around the world, opportunities to 'change career' or even change country whilst remaining within the network of firms.
cons: The firm (and prob most large consulting firms) is an agglomeration  of 'smaller internal businesses' each with it's own partner(s), director(s), team(s), etc. - your daily work life balance is determined by what 'business unit' you find yourself in - some can be great and long hours can result in great rewards, others can be a lot more challenging and long hours may just be taken for granted... make sure you're doing something you enjoy or at least that you are learning/growing so you can get to your own 'next step', else it can turn out to be an absolute meat grinder at times.

headline: Consulting Manager
pros:
- Very nice group of people in general
- Talent attraction: generally pretty smart and highly educated colleages. 
- Good/big clients: Usually FTSE 250 or similar global.
- Nice offices in London
- Fairly innovative with some good frameworks and IP
cons:
- Broken performance management and moderation process: It's not about quality of feedback but about quantity. People cheat the process by getting performance reviews from "buddies". If the feedback does not come from a Partner, or from an influential Director, it does not count. Also, it's tacitly accepted that one shouldn't really say any real development areas in their feedback. e.g. I was once given really good feedback, but this person didn't include any 'development' points in it because "they would use it against me in moderation".
- A culture that rewards wrong/less valuable behaviours: visibility and popularity is much more important than quality of delivery. It almost looks like quality, techical acumen, are very low in their scale. 
- At least in my experience I had two very unenthusiastic and untrustworthy People Managers. They completely set me up for failure when not being transparent about the culture of the firm mentioned above. 
- Pay is the lowest amongst the Big 4s, pretty tough to live in London with PwC salaries. But the talent and work is in London, so they should try to pay for it. Sad bonus scheme, and zero chance of getting a payrise if you don't get promoted.
- Greedy: The UK Partnership is among the most profitable of the PwC firms. This is on the expense of low pay to staff. How can they justify that the Avg Partner profit is 12 times a Mgrs salary? It's also around 6-7x a Director's salary. Is a Partner's value added 6-7x of what a Director brings? I am not sure. While Partners are in general hard working individuals, most of their role is Sales. Is an experienced Sales person paid 6-7x times more than a delivery person in other companies? Don't get me wrong, all Partners are in general fairly well experienced leaders that definitely made it there for a reason. I just think they could adjust their disposable income to level de staff's pay with the market.
Surely they are not in PwC just for the money? (At least that's what they preach to staff)

cons:
Management levels sometimes are far from inspiring. In certain cases, the people who stayed to progress into management level are not the best people. This is largely due to a rigid and highly subjective promotion system, which over time can  make people lose their drive to exceed expectation.

Good people leave because the pay is terrible. The "Partner" system is designed to eat out all profit and leave just a small small piece of cake to lower level staffs (who are probably working days and nights for them).

headline: Enjoyed my experience overall.
pros:
- coaching culture is very strong and intentional. 
- opportunities to be part of interesting engagements
- opportunities to interact with people in the industry
- travel opportunities for work
- great co-workers where everyone work as a team
- powerful branding that will get you to top companies in the industry
- managers generally do not micromanage you if you are able responsible and accountable
cons:
- can be very political. if you are not in the "inner circle" of the group, you will not be considered for a lot of good engagements and exposures
- senior associate levels and below are treated as a resource. if you are not sure what you want to do, you will just be parachuted to any engagement that requires resource, making you jack of all trades and master of none. 
- when it comes to yearly roundtable, unless you have a good strong relationship with various stakeholders, no one will represent you or speak up for you, thus adversely affecting your chance of progression and promotion.
- remuneration and benefits could be better

headline: Consulting has great people and challenging work, but burnout, travel, and long road to partner
pros: Work with great talent. PwC recruits thousands of college and experienced resources every year. You can work there for 5 years and work with different teams. Client work can be challenging and you learn a lot
cons: Travel is a grind, at Director level, the expectation is you carry the partner's water and travel to 3 or 4 cities a week. Ambiguous path to partner, based on fuzzy math, relationships vs. straight performance. Very difficult to make partner if you aren't located in a major hub (i.e. not in NYC if you are in Financial Services, not in bay area if you are in Tech).

headline: Great place to work!

Work with the best and brightest luminaries in your field, exposure to learn from the absolute top experts. Wide range of clients and access to diverse project types. Global exposure, highly international environment, and global mobility. Generous work flexibility, capacity for time off (but must be present when clients need you), and expense policy. Culture of celebration with frequent aperos, parties and events.
cons: "High performance culture" is rather intense. Expectations are very high, evaluations are competitive against one's peers, and one must investor hugely of oneself in order to advance and succeed - the only way to do this is to really be passionate about what you do.

headline: Narcissistic culture in Deals practice
pros: Opportunities to be involved in big projects and .  Good to have PwC brand on your CV.
cons: You need to be on the narcissistic spectrum to do well in the Deals practice.  The people that seem to succeed are those that are loud, self-promoting, pushy, selfish, super competitive and politically-minded. Bullying is rife, and there is very little by way of team spirit / collaborative environment.  Partners are focussed on bringing in the business and have suprisingly laughable leadership skills. The PR/spin relating to company values and ethics, flexible working, diversity etc. is not a reflection of the reality of working at PwC.

headline: Fosters self-actualization
pros:
o I feel I am appreciated within the business and that management care for my well-being. Further, there are opportunities for me to contribute my ideas for how things can be improved.
o Training is first-class, and equips me well to take on project challenges.
o Opportunity to work with very intelligent and capable people, who often inspire me to develop further
o Some scope for flexible working and travelling (if you state these as intentions)
o Career progression is subject to frequent review - if you are excelling in your role you can expect a favourable chance of promotion
o Entitlement to 25 days holiday/year and additional fringe benefits can be chosen according to your preferences
o Working in a nice office currently and we are set to move to new premises in summer 2020.
o Cut-throat culture does not exist here - instead the focus is on collaboration and maintaining a healthy work-life balance.
cons:
o In some busy times of the year, you may need to do overtime to ensure deadlines are met (50 hours + overtime in a month, but is paid). In my experience it has not been excessive though some other projects have had challenging time commitments.
o Starting salary is a little low, but I suppose calibrated to Belfast cost of living.
o We've outgrown our current office so can be a little busy/crowded in some respects, however are moving office within the next 18 months

cons: HR is a joke.  You have to form relationships with managers and partners to actually get things done.  Work life balance and many other "firm values" are not always the reality.  I was also a little disappointed with the formal training.  From what I heard from others I was expecting for tratining to be a lot better

headline: Superb People. Non Consulting Skills won't be Learned
pros: I had a management role in Advisory with professionals who were nearly all fantastic to work with, bright and engaging.  You can learn great core consulting skills like project management, data analysis, MS Office, how to most effectively communicate orally and in writing, etc. These are highly valuable and portable to your next job role and will serve you well.  It was great to work with the top management on highly pressing issues at some of the most prestigious firms.  The professional cachet of working for PwC is almost second to none.
cons: You will not learn any hard, technical skills that are used in industry that will get you your next role, but the consulting skills are valuable when you are in your next role.   If you encounter any struggles, don't expect help or coaching.  It's very Darwinian but that business model exists in many organizations.

headline: Everything that they tell you is true
pros: Recruiters tell potential new hires that the best thing about this place is the people. At PwC you'll definitely gain a wealth of knowledge from the experiences that you get from your fellow associates, through to your beginning days as a manager. The culture is young and thriving and does well to cater to the culture of Canada today.
cons: Management seems to not care about the direct recognition of their staff. Often times they will claim to want to be "new and innovative" but that does not mean giving people the chance to actually try anything "new or innovative". If you're shown to be good at something, be prepared to do that one thing over and over until you resign. Your worth to the firm is only in how well you can reduce costs to their engagements year over year.

headline: I like the Firm
pros: The firm is filled with career development opportunities to enable anyone who desires to tap into his/her strengths at becoming a value-added professional.  If you like learning new things.  If you like being around very smart people.  If you like being a part of the solution that eliminates business problems, then PwC is for you.  I am proud to work for the firm.  If one doesn't desire to stretch as a person, then PwC or any other professional services firm isn't for him/her.  The bottom-line is the people.  The people drive the business without a doubt.
cons: If a person is coming from Industry, then it's a challenging transition to make; which isn't a negative, but it can become one if the person isn't flexible enough to adjust.  What you hear often is the amount of hours that we work each week.  This is true as each employee is expected to be fully billable on his/her projects, and addition, must allocate hours to internal initiatives to help grow the business.  If one isn't strong at time management, he will soon feel overwhelmed.

headline: Good Experience Professionally, Horrible Management
pros: Having the name PwC opens up a lot of doors for you, and you gain exceptional experience.. worth it for a few years and to get your CPA license for free.
cons: Horrible hours. You’re expected to have no life for two months or more out of your year. I worked multiple weeks for over 90 hours and made myself sick trying to get everything done. Expected to work sometimes even if you’re technically on vacation. Horrible pay for how much you work. Every single person I know that has left has gotten at least a 20K increase in salary for less hours. Management has completely unreasonable expectations and doesn’t actually know how to manage people because the company does a poor job at training leaders. Management treats people like crap when they leave if it’s not in managements best interest. The list of cons goes on and on.

headline: Technology
pros: Technology is not something PwC is famous for globally. But in India, they have been in the business for more than a decade, notably before the IBM split in 2002. Post the end of the 5 year non compete agreement in 2007, the company has been trying to re establish its technology consulting practice. India is a crucial part of this strategy since a large part of the Internal Back office technology work for PwC US happens out of the India firm office. However, recent events including the Satyam episode has queered the pitch slightly and the Indian practice may not grow as much as originally planned/estimated. Overall fingers crossed.
cons: Lack of coherent vision in the Technology consulting space, too many variables keep changing. Lot of domestic projects with low margins means people need to be squeezed.

headline: Consider elsewhere
pros: Generous study leave, transfers available to other departments.
cons:
Considerable variance in both scope and difficulty of associate and senior associate Assurance client jobs. 

- No real clarity in performance appraisals system. Tendency to give middle of the road 3/5 scores with little explanation.

- Inflexibility both inside and outside of busy season. I know several colleagues working 14 hour days regularly between Jan - April. 

Stressful environment in general. Higher levels of management CONSTANTLY emphasise innovation and creativity while there is often no scope to apply to jobs. Many processes in your first two years of joining are labour intensive while you're often criticised for not completing at an unnatural rate of progress.

I've found management to be lacking in basic people management skills in general. The default approach is to belittle aloud in front of peers. Several managers have become known for this approach. No recognition of difficulty in reporting and ameliorating the situation. It's simply considered your misfortune while you risk diminishing your reputation.

HR department rather ineffective. Initiatives rarely touch base with employees, while employee training sessions are largely known as a significant waste of time. Little specific department training.

Most significant of all is the general lack of appreciation and value. New employees can be frequently derived and are there's a significant morale problem.

headline: Going Downhill Fast - All about the bottom line
pros: PwC overall has some pretty good benefits. Unlimited sick time, 5 weeks vacation (after 3 years), TONS of training opportunities (both in person and online), mostly good people. If you are in the offices, great culture, lots of good stuff.
cons: After a couple of years of Public Sector breaking off from PwC US, leadership has shown itself to not care about the people. They only care about utilization and the bottom line. Whereas at PwC US, the code of ethics includes how we allow clients to treat us. In Public Sector, all bets are off. If the client brings in money, they let the client get away with anything. If your utilization is down, you are automatically given a lower rating, no matter the circumstances.  You still get the sick time and vacation, but you really can't use it because you can't let your utilization drop. You are now a number instead of a person. It's actually sad it has gotten this way instead of how it was before the split.

headline: PwC associate
pros: PwC provides good experience for new hires and can act as a springboard when you decide to move on to another firm.
cons: Generally, the hours are longer and the pay is less than when working in industry. Turnover is high. There are too many senior managers and partners, which significantly slow your progression after the midpoint in your career.

headline: Great organisation but long working ours in audit
pros:
Lots of different nations working together 
High learning curve, great first job 
Great tools which allow for working efficiently 
Great internal communication, integrated Intranet with Employee Services
Company car leasing at an attractive price 
Proactive management that promotes professional development and ambitious people 
In Internal Firm Services, not a lot of overtime required
Entry salary is adequate (for Internal Firm Services) 
Manager salary seems to be really good
cons:
In Audit and Consulting, employees are expected to work unbelievably long hours
Internal Firm Services (where I worked) is treated very differently from audit, tax and consulting services, i.e. less opportunities for promotion, changing jobs within PwC working abroad etc. 
Some management do not have any people skills which means they shouldn't be in the position they're in.

location: Cambridge, East of England, England, England
headline: Great people, caring environment
pros: PwC hire fantastic people, and everyone goes out of their way to help. The office environment is friendly, and small enough for you to get to know nearly everyone. There are plenty of opportunities to get involved and there is always something going on. I feel like everyone really does put their team first and although there is a lot of work, you are always supported by your colleagues. There are many training opportunities so you can learn quickly. The firm is investing heavily in tech and constantly improving the tech environment to make work easier and more efficient.
cons: There is a lot to take in and because the progression of the graduate scheme is fast, you often feel that you are being stretched. Some jobs can feel understaffed so everyone always has a lot on their plate. The salary isn't the best compared to other grad schemes outside public accounting, however you receive a lot of training and time not working to study for exams, which the firm pays for.

headline: Junk Science
pros: At times, you work with great people.  Development of leadership skills is gold and if you are able to work on large listed clients, exposure to their top executives
cons:
An audit is a grudge purchase.  Even where clients are "appreciative" of audit staff, you are not dealing with issues that they particularly care to answer in order to take the company forward. Effectively audit is Junk Science, a way for people with some intelligence to pretend that they are learning important information with continual training and efficiency drives where really no progress is made at all in the end.

I was meant to be seconded to advisory, and had a terrible experience with management, who basically screwed me over.  If you want meaningful work, look elsewhere.

headline: Flexibility except for busy season
pros:
-There's a lot of flexibility outside of busy season hours. You're able to hide anywhere in the office and nobody will know where you are, or you could even work from home.
-Lots of happy hours especially if you're on a large engagement
-Really great people (only part of recruiting they were truthful about)
cons:
-Mobility across different functions very limited
-No work life balance during busy season
-Heard many stories of people being put on busy season after busy season due to lack of staff. I was lucky enough to be on a large engagement and was not pulled onto something else.
-Exit opportunities are limited since you don't have any product knowledge (I'm in financial services). Most people go into fund accounting, financial reporting, accounting roles, etc. Hard to make transition to a more finance role.

headline: Great starting point, but for the majority it is not sustainable.
pros: Working at PwC allows you to build a strong network of high performing individuals. It's a competitive environment, where you really test your limits to achieve high quality. You are able to gain exposure to a wide variety of clients and have numerous opportunities to step out of your comfort zone.
cons: The downside to promoting competition with your peers is that everyone continues to try and outdo each other. This counteracts any sort of team atmosphere that could exist, and perhaps promotes the opposite. Everyone trying to outdo each other ultimately leads to excessive pressure and workloads as you continually attempt to improve. This causes people to get burnt out without a feeling of satisfaction.

headline: Excellent Career in Professional Services
pros:
Culture & team environment - I could not say enough about the people I work with, from associates up to partners. People are highly motivated and take ownership in the team project. Coaches are interesting in mentoring the staff. Hard work and innovative thinking are appreciated and rewarded. 
Growth opportunities - Every day I learn something new. There is great variety in engagement work, even in Audit. There are opportunities to transfer to basically any major US city and to do international tours, though I have never done so personally. 
Flexibility - I feel the freedom to meet personal commitments and to work remotely as needed (less so during busy season). 
Benefits - Healthcare, vacation, life and disability - all are good benefits. Parental benefits are good too (maternity and paternity leave, adoption assistance, etc.).
cons:
Professional services - The client comes first, which means work can sometimes be unpredictable. You do your best to keep the client happy, even though the client often does not reciprocate. 
Worklife balance - This just comes with the territory in spite of every flexibility initiative there could ever be. The busy season is long and grinding, and it's not usually very slow outside of busy season either (in my experience).

headline: Glad I worked here for a year, even more glad I quit

cons:
-Too many people to manage effectively; allows low and mediocre performers to get lost in the mix and advance at the same speed as people who put in more effort
-401k is a complete joke. 25 cents on the dollar match with a 5 year vesting period.
-HR doesn't care about keeping people happy and will actively work against what you want if it means keeping you in their resource pool
-Pay is insanely below market, especially relative to hours worked
-Low morale; virtually nobody plans to stay here more than 2-3+ years so it kind of creates an "I don't give an F culture" among associates

headline: Great place to work, but..
pros: Progressive, inclusive culture.  Firm that takes good care of their people at it’s core.  Excellent values / mission, fair rating system and solid career development.  Allow and trust employees to work autonomously.  They care, family comes first.
cons: Flexibility and autonomy sometimes come at a price in terms of work/life balance.  Set a precedence and balance for yourself early on and try not to compromise other than when going the extra mile is warranted for client delivery/satisfaction.  Upward mobility takes time, requires patience along with strong performance.

headline: Great place to develop

headline: Not terrible and not the best
pros: In certain roles within the company, you are able to have lots of flexibility in your schedule.  Benefits are good as well.  You have 3-4 weeks of vacation time which is generous compared to many companies.  As the policy is not abused and used properly, unlimited sick days take the worry away about having to use vacation days.  The firm typically shuts down between Christmas and New Years which is great time off.  If you are in the external client service tax or assurance side of the business there is a steady progression and opportunity to advance.  If you are a mom, there are lots of roles that allow you to work on a flexible work arrangement schedule at a reduced workload (ie. 75%).
cons: If you are in an internal role, the compensation in not competitive and opportunity for raises and bonus are not there.  The company overall seems to be "reactive" more than "proactive" when looking at issues.  The 401k matching is not very competitive either.

headline: PwC Uganda 2018

headline: Marketing roles at PwC
pros: The company is very flexible - they offer the ability to work remotely; excellent benefits including healthcare. It is a friendly place to work.
cons: If you work within IFS (internal firm services) as opposed to client service, then you cannot get promoted, and pay raises are very minimal (even as a strong performer). The only way you can move up to another level is if a role at that level becomes available, you apply for it and get it. It is also very heavy in middle management within marketing, with limited support staff (associate/senior associate level). Therefore, managers/senior managers do a lot of the heavy lifting. Career growth is very difficult here.

headline: Company Review - PwC (Do not join)

2. Genuine people who join this otherwise hollow company, are fooled by HR into believing they are walking into a dream-land, where as the truth cannot be further from the fact. Starting with HR - they believe that they are actually doing a favor  by offering a job offer to prospective employees and have a "take it or leave it" attitude, which only smacks of down-right arrogance, absolutely down market corporate upbringing and attitude, which possibly stems from the over-inflated egos and packages of the IITs and IIMs who are hired in this company - who have absolutely no sense of ground reality.  Every partner here in PwC seems to be suffering from a deep sense of insecurity, malice and toxicity and if they feel a threat to their position - even from a junior person, they make the life of the other person hell.. by constantly discouraging, be-littling, down-grading and demeaning.  
2. PwC encourages a** - lickers, the more you lick the more you get - which means, irrespective of the knowledge and hard work - PwC values such tendencies, guess this is a fall over from the socialist india in the 1980s when these tendencies were rampant - PwC and probably the likes of it in the Big 4 space, dont deserve to even exist - what is the value they actually add to the economy? 
4. One of the most hypocritical and horrible set of people in this company who do not have other work than to pass snide remarks, judgments, build concretized false perceptions and ideas, keep pulling down and degarding - guess it comes from the fact that most Indians are cowards, no self-esteem, no spine and certainly no respect for the employee\

One of the worst companies and worst set of people

headline: Classic Bait and Switch
pros: The first day will be great because you will get a coupon for free lunch. 401K and some benefits are not bad as far as matching contributions. If you are paired with a good team,  you can work with some really nice  people who take time out to help you with an issue.
cons:
This is by far one of the worse companies I have ever worked for. How are you number one in the industry? It makes me think that some of these reviews are not 100% honest and that is horrible for people who depend on these reviews on Glassdoor when making a decision to apply. Some of the employees with a "title" are a set of the most unprofessional people imaginable. Training is subpar at best and the managers are clueless that their employees are being treated unfairly in their department(s). PwC reels you in with promises and everything that you want to hear to get you to accept the position. Once you are hired, the game changes and all bets are off.

Accept the position only if you have no other alternative. Most importantly, if you have an issue, personal or professional, do not go to HR. They make you fill out a survey and whatever you discuss in "private" is included in the notes of the survery. No one there is to be trusted as the "coach" that you are assigned to spies on you and runs back to report. 

Any time you call anyone for assistance, you fill out a survey. If you don't fill it out within the hour, you get a call asking you why you didn't fill it out. If you give any rating under "satisfactory" you get another phone call asking you why you didn't give a higher rating. You feel pressured into giving good reviews even when your issue hasn't been resolved. 

Intimidation and threats to be given a low score on your "progress report" if you don't ask "how high" when told to jump is the norm. My advice? Go in and do your time if you must. It looks good on your resume. But if you can, run and never look back after you have been there long enough to add them to your portfolio. Good luck!

headline: Good place to start your career with an accounting degree

- Flexible work culture and collaborative teams
- Be well, work well initiatives for employees' health wellbeing

cons: Wish that there could be more rotation opportunities

headline: Opportunities are endless, but so are the hours.
pros: PwC offers anyone the abililty to take charge of their career and grow as much as they want.  You can sit back and take the slow, easy road, or you can take opportunties to step up and advance quickly.  Recognition is given for the work you can perform, not the years you have been around.  There are numerous opportunities to try new areas and training is provided before taking on this new task.  Some of these rotations are short (6 months) while others go for a year or more.  It's also great that it is a global organization and international transfers, domestic rotations, etc are available and fairly easy to obtain.  I transferred between offices and the transition was a breeze!
cons: Work/life balance is hard to find.  Accounting used to be thought of us a job with certain busy times of the year, generally in the spring and again in the fall.  These days it seems that it is always busy and there is never a break.  Working 80 hours a week over and over again with pay that while seems great at the beginning, diminishes significantly with every additional hour worked.  One of the other big issues is that there is so much administrative work, its hard to find the time to do any real work.  We are so bogged down with risk management issues, checklists, time reporting, scheduling, etc that real work comes later and pushes the hour threshold yet again.

headline: Great for resume, not career.
pros: Obviously, the name recognition is important for launching your career.  There are many areas to gain general experience while trying to decide which path you would like to take within the company.  The trainings they have set-up for employees, from new hires to partners, is outstanding.  They make sure that everyone is extremely knowledgable.  You have the opportunity to travel for work and for training to various places around the country, while staying in 4 star hotels and eating at the finest restauratnts in each city.  Because the company is so large, it's easy to develop a network of friends.
cons: The number one downside to working at PwC is the work-life balance.  I understand the need to pay your dues, but when you work 80+ hours/week during busy season for 6+ months out of the year, you would at least like a bonus or some words of praise.  Management expects a lot out of employees, but is not willing to give or be understanding of employees' needs.  PwC makes a big deal out of the whole "work-life balance" idea, but that's just lip service.  Sure, they give you the opportunity to take time off and work 4 tens during offseasons.  However, nobody really is able to take advantage of those opportunities, and PTO goes unused.  I guess that makes up for the lack of bonuses.

headline: Great start to career - pros and cons balance out.
pros:
> Very good training and development programme.
> Generous benefits package.
> Colleagues are genuinely nice people.
cons:
> Salary is rubbish - no side stepping the issue.
> Hours are long - management appear to be understanding but rarely make concessions.
> Very tough to make a mark if you aren't outspoken and loud. 
> Favouritism plays a massive part in who gets the "nice" projects. 
> As with the other Big 4 firms, your performance on the job is irrelevant if you don't pass the the ACA exams (found this out the hard way).

headline: Bright spots & great brand, but what a mess internally
pros: So many opportunities - if you're young, interested in trying new areas, wanting to travel, this is a great place. It's a big place, especially when you take the global network into account.
cons: There are a lot of things that could be said here and I don't want to just run the place down unfairly. The one thing I'll focus on here: People go to work primarily for money, which arrives per performance reviews. You should see the creaky prehistoric piece of crap that is PwC's performance system. Shameful. It is so core to each employee's experience and it's so wrong that this company, which makes so much money, would shortchange its employees and managers with this system that really could be addressed in 2 weeks.

headline: PwC offers a great deal of opportunities and is a fantastic training ground.
pros: The people and the opportunities available throughout the firm. There are some great people in management, however there are few people who are pushed out of the firm so there is some variation in management, and often the best people are far too stretched as a result. There are huge opportunities there for the taking if you are prepared to commit yourself, such as secondments and varied work. PwC also offers a fantastic level of training, the first 2 years being a great learning curve.
cons: Work-life balance is pretty much non-existent. Also, bonuses in audit do not reflect the level of work, and there is huge disparity across the amount of hours worked which I don't feel is appropriately rewarded.

headline: Pwc Kolkata Sdc risk assurance A very unprofessional place with harassment and exploitation being rampant
pros: There are none as the work is more like a data entry job
cons:
Risk assurance management is extremely racist, biased and unprofessional, the leader of risk assurance and his directors are more interested in showing their ego than getting work done.
Believes that performers are there to cover up for non performers, no performance based assessments , if you speak up about challenges you are harassed, humiliated and targeted. If you give a good idea of development or value add you are not credited with it and the credit is given to the favourites of the management. 

Stay away from risk assurance as it is a very toxic place especially the management sitting in Kolkata which controls Bangalore as well.

Being forced to not take vacation time because of a client engagement, being forced to work Saturdays and a lot of the time for stupid reasons. Some managers are AWFUL at delegating and forget about you because they have so much going on that you sit there all day with nothing to do. Then once 6pm hits, they tell you everything they need done by tomorrow morning.

For the most part, all big 4 firms are the same, with the obvious exceptions of clients, industry specialization, and the actual employees working there. Just find what fits if you're interested, and be yourself during recruiting.

headline: Audit understaffing seems to be a never ending issue and pay is not reflective of stress/hours encountered long term.
pros:
- Sponsors you towards gaining the Chartered Accounancy qualification, all training material and tutors provided, high pass rates.
- Exposure to many big name clients can be great for you CV and family to boast about.
- Size of company allows large variety of opportunities to move internally where roles are available.
cons:
- Excessive hours for the pay given.
- Constant understaffing issues. The firm is recruiting heavily but isn't doing enough to retain staff.
- Senior management have been reluctant to improve pay and conditions for years, especially given the hours involved.
- Flexible working etc is very dependent on what grade/business unit you are in.  The firm preaches it but not all departments follow it.

headline: Audit work and approach that is sold as "consulting". Boring way to nowhere
pros: None. Waste of time and talent. Just follow the standard and be obedient and happy that you are working in a such "amazing" place. Might be an okish place to start the career (1.5-2 years max) but if you have an advanced degree from a good school - please forget all your career ambitions and intellectual capacity. It is NOT needed here.
cons:
Career progression is not based on merit but rather on whether partners like you - in other words, good work doesn't lead anywhere but constantly promoting your partner and doing minor but personalized pieces of work for him does
Boring, intellectually dull work that doesn't lead anywhere
Long hours and depersonalized environment where you are just an "augmentation gadget"
Management doesn't care at all about your personal and professional growth neither your opinion
A lot of nepotism 
Lack of respect and overall unhealthy professional environment

headline: Building upon you experience
pros: PwC is a very flexible company to work for, there are several opportunities to advance in your career.  PwC provides you with coaches and mentors to help you advance in your career, so if you are willing to work had and meet the right people you can go far in this firm.
cons: Some of the downsides is PwC is a large firm and sometimes you can get lost in the shuffle if you do not make yourself distinctive.  The other downside is, if you are in a large office, there is a high possibility that you will be working alot of hours and feel as though you do not have a work life balance.  The best thing to do in this situation is to make sure that you communicate with your team to importance of work life balance and take time off from work.

headline: Avoid

headline: Great Firm - But Superficial
pros: Outstanding networking opportunities, great learning opportunities, exposure to many different business problems and cultures
cons: Can you fit in at a fraternity? Then you'll rock at PwC. The key to a successful career at PwC is building your personal network and brand. That means being able to meet the right partners and demonstrate that you are able to add incremental value to the firm - and that you are a fit with the firm (in other words, the firm becomes your life/purpose for living). If you aren't able to grow the firm and you aren't a fit with the firm's culture, you won't succeed. Of course, all the other issues about working for a big 4 apply - it can be tough to balance work and family with a heavy travel schedule. While traveling, you'll frequently be working long hours at clients. The team events can get tiresome (see fraternity culture). Working for a partnership has advantages, but some partners can be capricious.

headline: Senior associate - London audit
pros:
- firm pays for ACA qualification and gives study leave
- opportunities to audit plenty of well known brands and companies
- Lots of young people in the firm which allows for good social life
- large firm so opportunities to second to a number of different areas eg. Deals, consulting, tax and a wide international network so can live abroad
cons:
- the company really takes its pound of flesh in exchange for the ACA. Long hours for awful pay in the first three years with overtime payments near non existent
- horrible work life balance, long hours throughout the year and not just the audit busy season. 
- audit work is very boring to begin with, only when you're near qualified does it get more interesting
- company is so terrified of being hammered under new auditing guidelines so ever more testing is being rolled out in the name of compliance, resulting in even longer hours for staff to tick more boxes
- negligible bonus
- constant staff shortages as everyone leaves when they qualify after having dealt with the horrible hours for 3 years

headline: Horrible place to work
pros: Great Benefits, that was it.
cons: Horrible place to work if you have a family to take care of. They don't care if you have someone you have to take care of at all; I had a manager tell me "Find someone else to take care of your responsibilities." Really? You're going to tell me to find someone else to take care of my kids? There is absolutely no work/life balance, sure they talk it up and say they have a great system in place, but it is just a façade, nothing but a lie. This is a great job if you are fresh out of college with no obligations and can work late, but if you are starting new but a little older, they have no compassion or understanding. Kept getting schedule 2 1/2- 3 hours from my home. When you have to travel 2 1/2 hours and have to be home by 8pm, that means you have to leave around 5:30. I asked if they could schedule me on clients that were closer to where I lived so I could spend more time in the office (which they did have) but they refused to accommodate my request. If you are in your mid 30's starting there be prepared to work with a lot of obnoxious people in there 20's, the company is pretty much run by inexperienced people with no heart. Also, my first 5 months after I started consisted of being "available." I sat around in the office for 8 hours a day waiting to see if anyone needed my help. I got paid to do nothing, which might sound good, but I also learned nothing and gained no experience.

headline: Wish I could give them a zero
pros: There are none.  The firm pays alot of lip service to feedback in the moment and being all inclusive.  Folks in my group were laid off without warning.  We had all received satisfactory snapshots prior to no notice layoffs.  Evil.
cons: Hired into the firm as an experienced hire.  No work after 5 months.  The firm wasted 2 weeks of new hire training on myself and some others.  Looks to me like the hiring and bench process is seriously messed up in US Advisory.  Be sure that if you are an experienced hire that you will actually bill as soon after in processing as possible.

headline: The firm itself is great, but your team could be bad!
pros:
1) Definitely a great career starting point for fresh grads, which allows you to explore the public accounting world and gain professional knowledge. 
2) Robust growth opportunities (only applicable if your team likes you)
3) A good looking CV meaning potential great exit ops.
4) Network. You would get to meet some great folks here.
5) Flexibility (depends on how your team carries it though).
6) Fairly competitive compensation/benefits.
cons:
1) Firm's core values doesn't mean the team delivers it the same way.
2) Toxic team culture. You might bump into a really bad team and have a miserable work life every day. (I witnessed a guy who quit within two months after being employed, I still don't think it's the staff's issues as of today.) 
3) 100 hours per week during busy season is an norm. The length of busy season and the amount of hours depends on your team. I know some people on my team literally enjoy the busy time, I personally don't. The promotion of "Be Well Work Well" is a joke. Some of my peers could easily continuously on busy season mode for most part of the year, tell me how to be well in that situation while you have no WLB, facing a bunch of folks who don't really value your existence.
4) Bad start on the team means you're pretty much screw over, good luck if your senior is not helpful. And get ready to pack if she/he doesn't like you for some reasons. 
5) Your personal life issues wouldn't be considered as part of your performance even though they look like they care at first. In fact, they expect you to be robots, no emotion, nothing would interrupt your work even if you're sick, they won't take into account that this might impact your quality of work because you're a robot, which shouldn't be affected by anything in your personal life.
6) The firm has an inclusive culture doesn't mean your team is inclusive. Last year I seek out for mental advice because I could not feel myself anymore.
7) No tolerance for mistakes, you're expected to be perfect.
8) Favoritism. Get ready to wear that mask if you're not an natural of complimenting your boss to get an easier life at work.

headline: Interesting projects, high profile clients, but highly political
pros:
- Flat org structure, early on working directly with partners, great exposure to senior people
- Interesting  jobs and opportunities to move around the firm or business unit
- High profile clients and exposure to senior client staff
cons:
- Promotions, Bonuses, Salaries! 

No transparency whatsoever. We are all treated like idiots with partners assuming that we don't know that the people on the same level are paid completely different salaries or bonuses. And I mean completely (juniors sometimes getting paid more than managers). Oh, not to mention this is not based on skills or experience either. It's about whether the partners like you. If you are the golden boy, you'll flaurish and get some fancy job titles and work internally... and get promoted and get a bonus, even if your utilisation close to zero. If you're not, even if your clients love you, but you'll not get far. 

Every year they do a survey where people rate this very poorly, and nothing, absolutely nothing has ever been done about this. Very political organisation.

headline: Mentioned pros and cons are established based on my experience as a Senior Auditor at PwC Azerbaijan.
pros: You will gain strong knowledge, competency and professionalism in very short term. In my opinion PwC Azerbaijan is one of the best options to apply for the graduates.
cons: Top management at PwC Azerbaijan is not competent. Approach to the business is not based on employee satisfaction. There is lack of employees within the assurance department. Employees are working more than 12 hours per day including weekends. Partner and other top management do not care their employees and quality of work. It seems main purpose of the management to satisfy the clients delivering them report in required time, sometimes before the contractual date as clients' want. No other benefits to the employees are provided. Moderation meetings are not fair enough. Upward feedback and whistle blowing mechanism do not work within the PwC Azerbaijan. ETC.

headline: Opportunity knocks, will you answer?
pros: Surrounded by very smart people, management takes a real interest in personal and professional development. Varied client interaction and opportunity to work with a wide variety of clients. Would recommend working in the business adivisory side in a smaller market if possible because you'll work less hours and have greater opportunity to work with a larger breadth of people both internally and on the client side. PwC has consistently shown a deep and genuine personal rspect for me. When my brother had a stroke, everyone went out of their way to ensure I had the resources, time and flexibility to manage the crisis in a way which benefitted myself, my clients and the firm.
cons: Some infighting and poor personal skills amongst young audtiors. Lack of real world experience with young auditors tarnishes the brand and can hinder client buy in. If you take the advice I gave above and work Advisory in a small market, you can expect to travel alot. I was on 100% travel for 14 straight months. It got to the point where I slept better in hotel rooms than at home. My plants all died and my girlfriend left me. Sacrifices are the nature of life however so you suck it up and move on. Another downside relates to the over developed sense of competition amongst some peers, but compared with other companies I've been with, the percentage of uber egos is pretty small.

headline: Offers great career opportunities but at the cost of work-life balance
pros:
Brilliant exam support through the tax learning & development team, flexwork policy specific to accounting / tax exams in advance of study leave. 
Continuous training re. people skills & tax technical knowledge.
Opportunities to work on large clients and complex projects. 
Approachable people including at the most senior levels, for the most part.
Good support available for people through the coach / appraiser and partner 'buddy' systems.
There is a willingness to invest in you and your career - partner 'buddy' system in place to have career discussions with people at the most senior levels - openness to facilitate secondments in Ireland / abroad, and career breaks/time off to travel after exams.
Great social events.
cons:
Very difficult to have work-life balance as you progress toward Manager level and above. It is acknowledged as an issue and there is a flex work policy in place at all levels that has somewhat helped. But at the end of the day the workloads are significant and can be relentless at times - as is the nature of the Big 4.

No access to the firm's pension plan - regardless of level - until you are 30. Ongoing issue for most employees under 30 who can be anything up to Senior Manager level, i.e. 8-9 years with the firm and no access to pension. You are provided a contact to set up a PRSA but there is no willingness to lower the age limit for entry to the pension plan.

headline: Client Strategy
pros: Good benefits, great teams. Ability to make connections with senior partners within the firm.
cons: The company treats internal firms services (IFS) as the step-child of the firm. In this role we drive revenue and sales strategy for accounts, but they do not support IFS in career progression. Furthermore, you can be a top performer at your level, but even if your salary is below average the most they can do for you in a good year is a 3% raise and mediocre bonuses - even if they give client service staff across the board salary increases and bigger bonuses. Needless to say it's worse in years of lower firm performance. Even if you do manage to get a promotion, they will only offer a 6% pay increase or get you to within ~80% of the lowest paid employee at that level. Meanwhile if you have to fill a role from outside all of a sudden there is extra salary available despite the fact there are additional on boarding and recruiting costs more to hire from outside rather than promoting form within.

-Pay is well below the market- No one cares how you think you came up with your salaries....you're not in line with the market no matter how many times you say you are.

-Upper Management is biased towards "certain employees" (...you can guess what I mean...I don't mean "high performers"...think more superficial...no matter how much they "promote" diversity)

-Hours are horrible- this may seem like it's getting better but it's only because they hired a bunch of people externally while they lose their best talent due to the above cons.
-No long term growth in this career as you will likely be automated in a decade or less so that the partners make more money.

headline: Awful human beings.  Even the "nice" ones.
pros:
- Great for resume.  Do it just for this reason .  Get out after 1-2 years.  
- 1 week shutdown for Christmas and NYE
cons:
- Awful people from associate to partner level.  You may have to be a bit of a psychopath or sociopath to stay here longer than a few years.  I don't see how nice, good people could remain there otherwise. 
- Senior Managers and Managers had cliques.  It's one thing if associates have a clique.  But for the leaders to create that atmosphere is really dissapointing.  Certain managers & senior managers never talked to certain associates ever.  It was unbelievable.  I've never seen that type of behavior (except in junior high!)
- Many of the "nice" people there eventually show their true colors by throwing others under the bus.

headline: Glorified Manpower Supplier
pros:
- Prestigious Brand to be associated with
- Cant think of anything else - Just filling this space to reach the 20 words minimum criteria.
cons:
-Under technology consulting - no credible consulting projects. Mostly into staff augmentation projects supplying bodies.
-Absolutely no work life balance. You are expected to work 24*7 - even on weekends and holidays.
-No strategy in place for team and capability development
-Recruitment done tactically based on clients requirement
-Partners rule - teams run on their whims and fancies
-No set policies across the firm - everything depends on ur partners whims and fancies
-Pathetic Guest houses - imagine torn sheets, dirty towels and bare toilets
-Travel and accommodation allowances are a pittance. 
-They expect you to book the cheapest accommodation in oyorooms. However partners get to stay in the fanciest of hotels.
-No seating space in office. When you request for more - they have the guts to say - we dont expect to see you in office, u shud be billed and working in a clients office. (actual conversation)
-Limited conference rooms
-No parking space in office and no transportation facilities provided. 
-No consideration given to a persons individual skills or development. You could be put in projects that are in no way linked to ur skill sets. 
-Resumes of consultants are modified left right and centre to suit clients requirement, even if the person does not have the required skills.
-News travels fast. Be careful of what you say to ur colleagues or over phone.

headline: Great place to start your career (Review pertains to Assurance)
pros: Invaluable experience in terms of coaching, growth, opportunities, perks (vacation time, holidays, health insurance, cell phone + computer, etc), and the caliber of people you will be working with.  Much more open environment than I expected for public accounting.   As long as you're doing a good job, the possibilities are endless.
cons: The big one is work-life balance.  You will work long hours and weekends at times of the year.  However, this was a reasonable tradeoff for me considering the growth that I experienced.  And this was also balanced out with opportunities to work from home during non-busy times.  Also notable that success can greatly depend on the engagements that you are put on early on and how well you fit in with the team leadership.  Management does a good job moving individuals around for a better fit though.

headline: Very Stiff, Snotty, and Non-Diverse Organization
pros: Big 4 Name and above average compensation, that's about it!
cons: Very Stiff, Snotty, and Non-Diverse Organization.  If you want a printer fixed you have to call the national support center, they forward your call to a 3rd party in India, they generate a ticket, forward it back to your local IT department (whom is also a 3rd party), then finally you get a call from a local IT rep and you have to re-explain everything.  If you want to work around a bunch of white cut throat auditors who claim to be the best of the best, be my guest.  Don't buy into the Philly.com 2015 top companies review - it's a big scam.

headline: Employee Reviews Based On Clique Membership
pros: Since PwC is an enormous multinational corporation, it's able to provide many benefits and discounts to its employees.  The healthcare plans, 401K matching, tuition reimbursement, and life insurrance are just some of the benefits that all employees are granted.  Great external benefits include discounts on things like cell phone usage and theater tickets to name a few.  And with PwC's particular lines of business it will never be in a bad financial position.  Grandiose parties and events are common.  PwC even throws a party for the families or its overworked staff.  Employees easily can get whatever software, hardware, or supplies they need for their work.
cons: Politics and cliques.  If you're not in a clique shared be a partner or senior manager, you can forget about major promotions or bonuses.  This was the over-whelmingly negative aspect of PwC in New York City, but it did not carry over to other branches.  There was an enormous amount of competition between staff to be put on the best projects, the top clients, or to performs certain types of work or skills.  The staff who was chosen to perform this work was chosen based not on the historical quality of that employee's work, but rather how good of friends they were with the project's manager.

headline: I am overall happy with PwC and my experiences here.
pros: I think that the training offered at PwC is very in depth and offer great experiences to learn and expand on your knowledge.  I also think that there is a big push to work on flexibility and the new strategies are starting to become more accepted. The teaming within the offices that I have worked in are great and it makes some of the long hours more bearable.
cons: I think the work/life balance still needs a lot of work.  There is a big push for the people to be constantly busy and with non-standard busy seasons the hours add up quickly.  I think the vacation and holidays that are given are great when you actually have the time to use it.  I believe that you can either push utilization or budget but not both as that is an impossible battle.

It provides a stimulating, high performance environment with a population of bright, young and dynamic professionals.

headline: Few Likes, Many Dislikes
pros:
Over my 4 years at PWC SDC, Bangalore below few notices.

- Cool Place to work
- Good Work Life balance
- Retirement like company, No much pressure.
- You will be utilized around 7 to 8 months a year on an average and the rest is all bench.
- Scope for new technology
- Just above the average salaries in the industries
- Good Short Term Onsite Oppty's (Just to northern states of USA)
- Insurance is real good in India.
- Good Chance to involve in COE and other practice development initiations
- Good fun at work and many yearly events and occasions.
- Good competencies in all technologies and professional.

Initially, I felt like leaving the organization as there are lot of issues with the management. I was not able to digest the policies and management microscopic management after working withe other CMMI 5 level companies. Later, after having thorough study on the internal management, understood that they need the followers and just followed what they say... Surprisingly, things followed well and could continue staying till now...
cons:
Many in list as we see in Pros.

- Management shows favoritism and Partiality
- Not an equal employment opportunity provider.
- works well for the management followers and very limited project.
- Experience grows but not the expertise.
- After working long, you will not fit to any good organization
- Onsite travel policies are not good at all.. not a place for onsite
- While in notice, treating employees is not good
- Management does not interfere in any project related activities..
- It is more like a body shopping company.
- Onsite insurance is mere waste.
- Reimbursement process is not easy and is a great inconvenience for professionals.
- All projects are partner based.. more focused on billing, and margin.

So, SDC has equal pros and cons. Up to the individual to decide. Somebody who is a technology freak this is not a good place. If somebody likes a cool place irrespective of the work, this is a place. Job is stable for full time guys. Follow with your manager and enjoy your stay.

headline: Made me utterly miserable
pros: Most of the people are great. Lots of opportunities for travel (not always glamourous) and to try different areas of the business. ACA qualification may be useful for finding jobs afterwards.
cons: Pay does not reflect the long hours, incessant travel and general negative atmosphere, and has not increased for 10 years. Expectation that staff will work long hours and have no life, due to an extreme shortage of staff, which the firm will not rectify as that would take money out of the partners' pockets. Ridiculous focus on 'winning work', selling and cold calling, despite the fact that we already have more work than we know what to do with. Audit is thoroughly miserable, and senior staff make it clear that we should always fudge the figures so the accounts get signed - this does not encourage junior staff to show any integrity. This job has changed me from someone happy to work hard at something I care about to someone who resents every extra minute of unpaid overtime. Don't do it.

headline: Summer Associate

headline: Great people to work with in an environment that fosters competition, but low compensation when compared to its peers
pros: One reason - the people.  The breath and depth of people's expertise in a strong big-four consulting firm are difficult to match by the competition.  During these last two years, the consulting arms of the the big four have increased the size and scope of services they are able to provide clients.   This growth increases the opportunities to engage different types of projects and gain expertise.  This is a great environment for someone who likes learning and new challenges.
cons: Traveling and politics - Expect 90% traveling in advisory.   Politics is more complex than usual because you have dozens of "boses" depending on the project, service, industry, market, etc. Also, for the traveling and work hours, compensation is lower than industry and when compared to its peers.

headline: Competent and hard-working consultants, insufficient support, politically correct, work-life balance issues
pros:
1. The overall staff quality is very good: competent and motivated.
2. My own management team was excellent; assignments were challenging, and management appreciated my contributions.
3. The deserving clients with whom I worked needed our help, and like my management, appreciated our team's contribution to improve their processes and performance.
cons:
I was not impressed by corporate PwC:
1. The headquarters politics and the broadcast communications of the firm were very politically correct.  Their particular flavor of political correctness had the feel of a "cynical embracing", rather than actual enthusiasm, which would have been easier to appreciate and/or understand.
2. The Annual Review process was very opaque.  One is evaluated by a committee of people that have not met or worked with the reviewee; they do not know what the reviewee does, except for the broadest strokes. Mechanical measurements are emphasized over one's own management's evaluations.  The focus, even at the non-managerial level of Senior Associate, seemed to be on business development, rather than task performance.
3.  Work-life balance.  Across the firm, PwC has a culture of heavy overtime, especially for Managers and above.  In fact, if one chose to balance work and life, it was likely to be reflected negatively in one's next assessment cycle.
4. There was minimal support to team members at remote or smaller offices.  PwC places an enormous emphasis on meeting the annual training requirements.  However, almost no classroom training of any kind was offered locally (in my smaller market office), and despite plenty of technology, the firm does not offer much in the way of distance learning for the Advisory government consultants.  Most of the training available were self-study online courses.  While the Skillport online classes are adequate as familiarization or reinforcement to certain  business subjects, an actual instructor, as well as classmates with experiences to share, are much more valuable.
5. PwC's corporate financial systems were hard to access, confusing, and time-consuming to use (timesheets, expenses, travel systems).

b. All employees below Associate Directors are assigned to monotonous work - which is mostly completing internal risk processes or formatting sheets.

headline: Good early experience, but too easy to get pigeon-holed and no real long-term development opportunities
pros:
High Profile Clients
Some very smart colleagues
Travel 
Educational Support

This is a matter of good fortune - I was lucky enough to work in a small department that allowed me to travel the world and work on blue chip clients - however some of my colleagues never left the office and never set foot into a meeting with a client or partner.
cons:
Heavy workloads
Poor planning and resource management
Poor rewards - both financial and non
Bad talent management and opaque appraisal/promotion system

All in all there is a steep but good learning curve in the early years - however once you reach AM /Manager level additional skill learning drops off and it becomes more a delegation and review role. 

It is very easy to get stuck and specialised - if you are doing one thing well, and it helps out thise senior to you,  it can be hard to move into a new area. Senior management get very protective and possessive of good staff and this can eventually lead to them leaving the firm if they want a change. 

Identifying and managing talent is something of a weak-point in the firm sadly.

-like any large organization, changes can take a long time to be implemented or executed
-due to high turnover, there's always a need to constantly train new staff

headline: Meh
pros: Great vacation, Great Benefits, Stable Company, Opportunities are there if you love client service and want to work in consulting
cons:
The expectation that you have to work 80 hours a week to accomplish your job and get a good performance rating, no work life balance.  Partner team varies, but for them it is all about the bottom line and what our clients need, versus are the staff happy, do we have enough people and the right skills sets to do the work.   

Recruiting arm is one of the worst I've seen in the commercial industry. 

Minimal opportunities for outside training, which are needed in highly skilled fields, such as cyber security. 

The partnership is too big, so decisions are not easily made.  

No clear cut management chain, makes it hard to navigate and get opportunities if you don't find a partner to align to.

headline: Toxic and biased culture, don't let the branding fool you
pros: PTO and other benefits, modern office, intelligent people, some flexibility and freedom to try other LOS, casual dress code, benefits
cons: Terrible management, this office is an old school boys club all the way. Politics reign and your superiors will stab you in the back while smiling to your face. Expect to receive passive aggressive emails at all hours of the day/night. Favoritism is off the charts, it doesn’t matter what your chargeability or performance reviews say, if the people in power don’t want you promoted you won’t be. This goes both ways too, with highly incompetent people who lack technical ability and/or management skills being promoted.  The pressure to “eat” hours is huge because most projects are won with lowball bids. This is the only way for directors/partners to meet their goals. There is no system for upward feedback whatsoever. The pay is pretty bad comparatively, raises/bonuses are below market standard. Lots of restructuring and turnover in HR and other internal services has led to tons of extra administrative (unbillable) hours for staff.

headline: PwC is a place you'll probably love to work, but beware that they'll love to work you...extremely hard.
pros:
PwC is a great place to work if you want some free education while you work. The firm offers week long (off-site) training sessions specific to your line of work, online tutorials, teleconference seminars, IT Learning & Education, and numerous other "education" opportunities. Additionally, as you move up in the firm, there is coaching geared specifically for the management level and above.
PwC is also great for meeting people and developing a network. There are lots of knowledgeable, well-connected people there who are usually willing to include you in their circle of friends.
For the most part the leadership is part extremely qualified, treats everyone with respect (even new associates/new hires), and will recognize a job well done.
The firm tries to communicate clearly with its employees, and if anything, there is so much communication that it is impossible to keep up with it all.
More than anything, the people you work with can be the best part of the job.
cons:
I believe that management has been ordered to work new hires to death. Since pay is salaried and there isn't really overtime (maybe a spot bonus here and there), i think the motto is "milk them for all they're worth". As a new associate you will be told that you are expected to work long hours and to have a "utilization rate" of at least 80% according to HR policies. That being said, however, as a new hire a likelier story is that you should really be at 100% since other people in the office have utilization rates of up to 150% (or something ridiculous like that). If you have 8hrs of billable hours a day you have a 100% utilization rate, so you can do the math to figure out what 150% would be. "It's not uncommon to work 12-14 hours a day", according to many managers. And if you ask, like me, how does that leave time for the rest of your life?? You might get a similar answer- "well, the work has to get done". Work/Life Balance is a joke!

Also, the push on new hires comes from the fact that they have the lowest billing rate and budgets are ALWAYS tight. That can be pretty stressful.

So again, the biggest downside would be the long hours. VERY LONG HOURS. If you are okay with that for the rest of your life, and especially as a new hire, then PwC is the place for you. But be aware, for the amount of time you work, the salary isn't that high and the spot bonuses for overtime are weak to say the least.

The last thing is that sometimes credentials take precedence over proven abilities. So much emphasis is placed on PhDs and advanced degrees, but having those degrees does not necessarily make the person the best one for the job or even the smartest (it seems like every one at the office is always having to prove how smart they are!). I'm extremely proud to work for PwC and with the people there, because i think they really are very talented and bright, but sometimes it goes to their heads. Eh, most of the time maybe...

cons: 1. No cons at the firm level, now it depends on the project you fall in and your expectations. Eg. Someone who has been working in IT service companies, might not like it here for the way of working is not too process oriented. But if you are open to change, you can learn alot of thhings which are not accessible in any rigid hierarchical environment in IT sevice firm.

headline: Not the best choice for graduates
pros:
Just anounced payrise for a small percentage.

Intelligent people to work with.

Good application to up to date software and applied data tech in audit process to reduce work load.
cons:
ACA Qualification mainly self learning based. My advise is if you are not good at self study choose another big 4.

The pathway is horrible with limited support. Very time pressured. Need to take own holiday to study constantly. Much lower passing rate and fails for difficult papers such as tax.

Firm support is very limited. Students were not allowed to pay extra to get personal tutor from training school coz 'firm believes that extra course is not needed' which is apparently not the case.

And yet this pathway will continue in use because it is much much cheaper.

Feedback process is subjective and unfair. Too much office politics and no work life balance with demanding managers.

Great terrace in Moscow office!
cons: Senior people in other departments can be really intimidating (but I think that is more of a culture thing in Russia in general), however that was rarely so. In other departments there is definitely an unsocial hours issue, at HR less so - still can be very busy at times

headline: Great in the early years
pros:
The diverse opportunities available.
The range of young people training together and learning. 
The wide range of sectors I worked across
The skills and experience I gained
cons:
Whilst wonderful flexible working schemes are lauded they don't happen in some of the more regional offices.

The travel got relentless, increasing over the years.

 It used to be that individual offices could take their own commercial decisions. But it became more centralised over the years which made us out of touch with the local market.
I found flexible working to be almost impossible. Lip service was paid but you were limited significantly in your career on coming back from maternity leave and a culture crept in of "being present" at all hours which never used to exist.

headline: The future is bright
pros: Powerful brand opens doors. Great new office at Barangaroo. Big on flexible work and diversity. If you deliver you will be rewarded handsomely. High calibre pool of professionals to draw from for assignment work. Great for offering multi-faceted solutions for clients due to the broad range of service offerings within the firm. They take further education and development very seriously and back individuals who wish to add qualifications (subject to successful business case)
cons: Although it's PwC Australia is one firm in a global network of firms, internally it feels a little divided as Partners and Directors are assessed based on bottom line of their own business units yet there is overlap in services provided between some business units...can make people defensive and inhibits true collaboration between some parts of the business... difficult problem to solve although I admit this problem is acknowledged and is being fixed gradually. Also pays less than ops outside the Big Four - they tend to use the carrot of promotion to get more out of people for less. Final con is there is a lot of process and the internal IT systems are inefficient.

headline: Horrible
pros: The only good thing I got out of PwC was the name on my resume. I met some nice other associates that I have stayed friendly with
cons:
The people are arrogant when they really shouldn't be since most people I met weren't that smart. The associates are there to do the tedious work, even work the EA's were supposed to do. Regardless of how busy you were, you always needed to make time for another project since you are an associate and were technically not allowed to say no.

As soon as I could get out, I got out and ran. Friends at other companies were getting paid a lot more...

headline: Great learning experience, but comes at a great cost

headline: Lots of opportunities until you are ready for admission to partnership.
pros: Smart hard working peers.  Your will learn a lot and will work with talented and energetic people.  Work hard and you can gain skills and knowledge and you can advance and can advance quickly in the early years of your professional life.
cons: Work vs. life balance can be very hard if you want to advance and to work on the best engagements.   Promise of partnership is appealing, the reality is much different.  After 5-6 years of getting the highest possible rating and metric at the level just below partner and performance equaled or exceeded the partners I worked with on a day to day basis I was passed over for partner 3 years in a row.  I am a white male and was passed over to make up for under representation with racial minorities and females.  I agree the firm's partnership was overly dominated with white male, but the solution should be to remove the underperforming and make room for those that are make the firm's money and reputation.  Also the closer you get to partnership the more you realize that most of the partners are really highly paid staff without any control, input or decision making authority.  My advice  from someone who has been their is to join the firm grow your skills and contacts and leave on your own terms.   I did and couldnt be happier.

headline: Advisory - Manager - 5y - Recommended for Rapid Career Development, w/ Caveats...
pros:
1. Opportunity for rapid career growth (skills, network, and professional credibility)
2. Opportunity for exposure to wide range of industries and roles, and easy to bridge experiences into the next job
3. Opportunity to work on and solve interesting problems
4. Starwood points and luxury travel (if you are into that kind of thing)

Net net...
I recommend consulting to anyone early in their career who receives an offer, but does not have a professional passion that they would regret NOT pursuing instead

If you decide to go into consulting...
Make your decision based on the quality of the partners/team you will work with. They will greatly impact your career growth and how much fun you will have. 

If you don't have the opportunity to interview directly with your future teams than I'd recommend MBB > Big 4 > Niche. But IMO you will make faster gains in a great situation at a less prestigious firm than they will make in an average situation at a more prestigious firm.
cons:
1. Although work/life balance is championed, it is not culturally understood
2. Comp for is formulaic and cohort-based below director-level; top-performance is ranked but not (significantly) rewarded
3. PwC is not perceived to be as sexy as MBB

Risks
1. Career growth and/or quality of life will be a function of the partners you work under; some people get lucky and others get screwed
2. If you don't have a skill that differentiates yourself from the crowd you will be a commodity and you will not work on stimulating projects that will advance your career

headline: PwC a great place to work.
pros: The firm has an excellent reputation and works hard to make PwC a great place to work.  The firm provides great formalized training, as well as a superior on-the-job learning environment with exposure to management at top companies.  The majority of the people I had the pleasure to work with were intelligent, motivated and considerate.
cons: There is little control over your own life and while the firm claims they are concerned with work/life balance, I found this to be untrue.  The annual review and promotion process was, at times, biased and unfair and did not adequately reward individuals for the work performed.  The travel schedule and hours were tedious and made it difficult to manage life outside of work.  Compensation was not inline with other firms in the market and was not appropriate for the level of work performed.
