headline: Not a positive experience
pros:
Variety of work (for some).
Young work environment, social.
Progression path clear.
cons:
A negative environment to work in, plenty of expectation for you to work overtime with no benefit or recognition. Coupled with such a low starting salary this could potentially leave you working at less than the minimum wage. Wave good-bye to your work life balance.
Favouritism from senior management is evident, end of year review process is therefore biased also penalised in year-end moderation if you are working on projects in a different department than your team despite having no choice and bringing in revenue. Awesome.
High staff turnover.
Pay in comparison to all other UK regions is pitifully low.
Role models in the company are few and far between, especially females.
You have little to no say in whether you travel or not, not ideal if you have children or other commitments outside work - again work life balance is completely compromised.
Some team leads/managers should not be in their roles - I have been bullied by some, thrown under the bus by others, had my personal life questioned and been belittled over things beyond my control.
Work can be mind-numbingly boring or incredibly stressful.

headline: Complicated company
pros:
- Some very smart people who do care about doing good work - find them, and work however you can for them.
- Brand still means something - and management consulting is an interesting space to be in.
- The variety in consulting work is fascinating
cons:
- VERY political atmosphere.  It's about who you know.
- Utilization matters more than if you're a consistently good performer.  I was laid off because there wasn't enough 'work for me to do', but had no visibility into sales cycle.  
- Travel and more travel.

headline: Terrible work-life balance
pros: PwC was a good place to start my career. Since I worked a gazillion hours in just 2 years and 9 months of real time, it's as if I'd worked full-time for four or five years. I left PwC 2.5 months ago; now I hold my own (from a technical expertise perspective) with finance and accounting professionals several years older than me.
cons: The work-life balance is terrible. Every year, January, February, and March were hellacious. In 2017, I worked 52 consecutive days from Jan 3 to Feb 23, with many days involving 10-14 billable hours. This included seven consecutive weekends. I averaged 65+ billable hours per week. With a year-round client that's an SEC registrant, work-life balance continued to be bad in the quarterly review months of April, July, and October. Therefore, take 3 months of busy season, plus 3 more months of quarterly reviews, and 6 months of the year I rarely had flexibility. My mental, physical, and emotional health deteriorated; I was becoming a one-dimensional person with limited time to invest in family, friends, hobbies, or physical exercise. I started a new job with a non-Big Four accounting firm 2.5 months ago, and my work-life balance and happiness are significantly better. The grass is truly greener on the other side. I work fewer hours, yet I am paid more. Work smarter, not harder. Self-care is so important and so necessary!

headline: Salesforce Practice

The technology (Salesforce) practice I am in is growing rapidly, which is exciting as the firm are putting their weight behind it, so the pace of change is good and there is a wide variety of projects.
cons: Not suprisingly for a firm this size, internal processes can move slowly and making a real impact is difficult for one person to do.

headline: Audit Manager - Good for exposure fresh out of uni but don't stay too long
pros: Fast paced environment, lots of exposure to various industries, most of the people you work with in their 20s and early 30s. You get a mentor whom is your point of contact should you need help/direction. Certain level of flexibility at work from managerial grade onwards which is helpful for staff with young families.
cons: Ridiculously Long working hours, not much recognition for hard work and going the extra mile, putting up with nasty clients as it's all expected of you. Bosses tend to not get their hands dirty and try to understand the challenges faced by staff. The burnout is real and a lot of staff suffer from health issues due to the demands of the job. Morale is generally Low and everyone keeps on talking about quitting. So difficult to take leave because of non-stop deadlines. Work-life balance is literally non-existent.

headline: A strong employer who understands the need to hire and retain good people
pros: The firm offers a tremendous amount of benefits, including unlimited sick days, up to 22 days of vacation, and a paid sabbatical as a promotional bonus.  In additional, all levels have opportunities to earn annual performance bonuses, and leadership worked very hard to avoid layoffs during the recent economic downturn.  They are also very honest about what is expected of personnel, and are generally fair when it comes to compensation, promotions, and recognition.  Everyone has the opportunity to manage their own career, and I have personally seen leadership support transfers to different practices in order to help personal career growth.
cons: It all depends on your partner.  Application of all of the above varies between partners and practices.  Partners also can be very competitive, which can impact those working for competing partners.  Recent changes in performance evaluations have made the process less transparent, resulting in staff distrust in leadership.

headline: Distinctive.
pros: Flexibility and ability to move up the ladder if you work hard. A fairly open performance review policy leaves everyone knowing where they stand with enough due diligence on the part of the employee. Any employee who says they dont "understand" how we are evaluated has clearly not been paying attention. If you ask and prove that you are ready for more responsibility, it will be given to you. The firm seems to value relationship building with clients and technical expertise. The relationships are often more important than the technical expertise on a daily basis and this fits with our overall business model.
cons: Long hours, tight timelines on client demands, never ending measurement of utilization and revenue metrics. There is a push to be all things to all people - a good coach to staff, from a technical and professional development standpoint; giving back to the community, working on 10 projects at the same time while keeping work life balance in check and utilization high. Taking vacation is important but so is utilization and one can't do both well in any given month. Compensation seems like it could be higher in order to keep solid performers. They may leave anyway, but at least comp won't be one of the driving factors.

headline: Great place to work if you don't want a life outside of work
pros: Great place to start a career, learn valuable accounting skills, financial reporting, infinite learning opportunities, great training programs, dynamic/fast paced environment, interaction with top management at clients from the start.  A very nice perk is you don't have a direct manager so you can often do your work on your own time.  I laugh when my friends have to stay till 5 every friday no matter if they have work or not.  If you don't have anything to do...which is rare, but still, you can take off without anyone knowing or caring.  Ample time off if you can take it, 22 days after 2 years and since I've been with the firm they have given us 4th of july week or xmas week off and sometimes both.
cons: Work life balance is terrible, not sure how many more busy seasons I can take.  Colleagues often don't respect time off..i.e. they call you on weekends and when you are vacation.  The more effective an employee you are the harder you are worked.  Compensation is not inline with how many hours you work, bonus / overtime hours is often less than minimum wage.  Management is a bit out of touch with directing the practice, I just don't think career accountants make good managers.  Specifically things are always changing, I'm not against change but when you are doing the same thing a different way it makes tasks more time consuming

headline: Need to be a very specific type of person
pros: Good reputation as a global firm and a global brand.
cons:
Horrible politics. You need to be “one of the pack” to standout enough to get chosen for the good jobs and be promoted past associate. From what I’ve seen, they are more likely to shaft you at the Auckland PwC as well if you’re a transfer - say goodbye to opportunities to show that you’re good for a promotion cause these will be given away to the locals and those in good favours with the managers.

Also, if you muck up once, “everyone talks” and nobody will want you as part of the team or leading the team. Unless you can get a good coaching family/manager that will stand up for you (most of these guys are too busy to really help), you won’t go far either.

Pay is poor, but that’s to be expected as you’re working for the “reputation”.

Pay and 401k match is much lower than you could find elsewhere (there is a pension though). When I tested my value in the job market, I got a 25% base pay increase, 300% 401k match increase and my benefits are also much better at my new company. Also, my personal life suffered from the amount of time I had to spend at work.

headline: Fairly positive review
pros: PwC is a well respected firm, similar to the other Big 4 firms, I assume.  You can work on large public clients and have great learning experiences.  It will also look good on your resume if you determine to go elsewhere.  You may have the opportunity to travel to exciting locations and might have the opportunity to work on several lines of services (audit, advisory, tax, etc).
cons: Long hours, potential for travel.  It could be tough to balance the experience gained by staying longer, with the cost of pricing yourself out of the market when you are ready to leave public accounting.  Not everyone can (or wants) to stay and become a partner.

headline: awesome company
pros:
Fast growing company, with lots of opportunity.Hardworking people, very team oriented, promotions are given to people who earn it not much is based on how much you're liked. Frequent and honest feedback is encouraged. Very good work life balance and based on how hard we work. Complete detachment is encouraged during PTO/Vacation.

Utilizes new technology such as Goggle Mail to attract younger professionals. Great office party. Promotes physical and mental health.
cons:
Its hard work... which is not a con but if you're not a type A leader kind of person you won't succeed or at least you won't succeed rapidly. 
Sometimes management can get really busy so its hard to communicate but to counteract this PwC encourages reverse manage. Meaning lower staff can give feedback to upper staff and it isn't held against you because promotions are based on work quality. Very much a people life, but quality and numbers do not.

No really cons. I love working here. I'm doing what I love with plenty of options to try other things.

headline: People Oriented Culture and Leadership with Great Vision
pros: PwC has done a great job leading people and the business during the Pandemic. Their concerns for employees and the emphasis on their emotional and physical health was a testament to how much they care for their people. While many other companies in the industry were resorting to lay-offs and furlough programs, PwC has not only provided sense of security, but also promoted people, gave salary increases and bonuses. In fact, for the first of ever in the history of the firm, they gave salary hikes in middle of the year. Keeping the financial rewards aside, the level of support, care, and assurance for job security helped employees significantly to stay healthy in this challenging times.
cons: Overall the firm culture is great and supports diversity. However, unfortunately, there are some pockets where a lot of bias and discrimination takes place. Favoritism and discrimination rules over hardwork and talent. This will soon catch up and will lead to brain drain.

headline: Salary
pros: Great flexibility, lots of different options in terms of trying new things, great training courses, international travel, large network available

headline: Demanding job with great employer that invests in its people
pros:
The company invests heavily in your career, providing you with all the tools, opportunities, support and education you need to move your career along. You work with highly motivated, professional people in a culture of mutual support, self-betterment and opportunity. 

You are always developing new skills. You'll be given opportunities to do many things you have not done before. Doing so is encouraged so you can be a better consultant for your clients. It also helps you advance your career at a much faster clip than working in industry where you do the same thing over and over. 

The company provides a highly-supportive culture, making sure you have the tools and the staff support to get high-quality work done. You never need to beg for a resource. 

PwC makes available innumerable training courses for which you do not need to get signatures for approval to attend. If you want to take a negotiations course, and you jump on a plane and go take the course. That's it, all paid for and no friction. PwC leaves your career choices up to you, providing you with great opportunities for self-betterment and advancement.
cons: The high expectations can be stressful. Travel can be significant. If you have a family, it can be a tax on it.

headline: Learned a lot. Some great people. Some terrible managers.
pros:
You really do learn financial statements outside and in; cool if you ever want to play the stock market. 10k's are your friend- that is if you pay attention to what you're doing. You get some nice relaxing time every once in a while and the Company means well. Lots of client interaction; most invaluable part of the whole job.
Also, you will definitely find best friends; guarantee at least some people will have an incredibly well-developed sense of dry humor. Audit brings it out of you.
cons: Some of the managers are not well-suited to managing teams and managing them can be really stressful. The review system is ridiculous; every psychology book out there explains why this system is incredibly poor for fairness as well as employee motivation. And you really do sacrifice a lot of life outside of work- hard to make plans. But if you like who you work with you can make that work for you for a while.

headline: Great for client facing roles, support roles are hit or miss
pros:
Well known brand name company looks good on resume.

Good benefits.

Good development opportunities for client facing staff, for someone in accounting or consulting it's a great way to start your career.

High quality furniture.
cons:
Limited to no opportunities for development for support staff. For support staff, areas such as Marketing, IT and HR show high-turnover, which does create opportunities for advancement. Areas such as Accounting, operations and administrative support tend to stagnate.

No raises to speak of for the last decade. 

Annual reviews are strongly biased towards project work, so staff in administrative positions struggle to distinguish themselves. Management have a limited number of 'above expectations' they can award staff, decided in a round table meeting. Who gets rewarded is based more on popularity than merit.

headline: High highs, low lows
pros: When landing certain roles with certain people, it can be fantastic working at PwC. They also have great family leave policies compared to most companies in the US (though there is always room for improvement). There are lots of great people who work here, and they do try (and sometimes succeed) in making it a forward-thinking, exciting place to work
cons: New Advisory leadership doesn't seem to be investing as much in professional growth, people development, L&D and other such things; they hope people will do these things out of the goodness of their heard but don't want anyone to invest the time (or rather take the time out of the market and not be profitable) to contribute. These things are critical for consultants to be competitive in the market and to give a competitive edge. A lot of times the firm can get in its own way and this is frustrating and the antithesis to being productive. Also, the travel lifestyle is horrific. This is true of all consulting companies. But I expect that PwC, who preaches flexibility, would make more accommodations and work harder on local staffing options - ESPECIALLY for moms who have just returned from maternity  leave and cannot be on the road.

headline: Think twice before joining
pros:
Smart people below the manager level 
Flexible working in some cases
Nice office location
cons: The working culture is deteriorating  every year. Expect to be treated like a property. They do not care about you but only about their fees. They push people into doing free overtime whilst they charge the clients higher fees for this overtime. Expect to be working with unrealistic deadlines so that managers can maximise profits. Be careful on the term and conditions of the employment contract as PwC will  make everything to trap you for their benefit. Bonus for an associate in assurance is £150 and that's a real example. Coffee chains pay more in bonus to their employees. The job in audit is pointless and extremely boring. It adds no value to any client. PwC spends so much money on PR to present itself as the  elite firm but inside is rotten. So overall a big mistake to join this firm. There are other jobs and companies out there that are worth working.

headline: Not a great place to work for most people.
pros: Constant change - if you like that.  Nothing stays the same.  Teams change all the time.  Office changes all the time.  The name of your group, team, and company change regularly.  If you like the excitement that accompanies a lot of change, you get it at PwC.
cons: Long hours, not a meritocracy.  Success based almost solely on self-promotion abilities.  Every man for himself.  Not at all conducive to team work despite propaganda.  A lot of arrogance among senior managers, directors and partners - very unjustified.  Disfunctional internal management despite the discipline of advising others on the issue.

headline: Ex-Consultant
pros: Free internet, young ppl around you. Travelling. Learning opportunities.  Immense work load which will train you well. Free alcohol and parties.
cons:
Have been getting good reviews about my performance. Got terminated for a minor mistake. Conclusion was made in one day. Positive reviews were not considered at all. Have been working hard for the company but did not get respected. The "reimagine the possible", "care" and "hunger for growth" values are not real. 
The firm cares so much about their image and reputation. Worse comes to worst, they will terminate a good employee for a minor mistake. 
A lot of politics going on in the firm and you will never know what happened. 
Personal advice: Keep in mind that you are working for your own good, not for the firm.

headline: Great company to work for but good people can get overwhelmed
pros: Great people, facilities and opportunities.
cons: Can easily become involved in a yes culture, where you take on too much and work extremely long hours. You can manage this more the longer you stay, but some who are joining the firm are expected to be working unsociable and long hours.

headline: A2 option
pros: If you develop a partner relation they'll look out for you and advocate for you. Focus on diversity (excluding neurodiversity) and prioritizing I&D conversation on teams. Support from in pursuing ideas you think can be beneficial.
cons: The HR team isn't great and unless you have someone from a manager or partner-level advocating for your interest you have little control over your own career. As a new hire, you have little choice of what you work on. The firm messaging can be very contradictory to their actions. Personally, I have dyslexia (still a high performer) but when I reached out to HR for resources (proofreading software, connecting to a diverse group, and changing my coach) they were very toned def and I was the first person in my market to do so. After creating partner relationships, advocating, and openly discussing this disability the firm is slowing starting to handle this better. The hours are also insane and very understaffed. Health insurance is not great.

headline: Work environment

headline: Great Flexibility and Opportunities to Gain Consulting Skills
pros:
The firm has focused on expanding their Advisory/Consulting practice, which has led to a great variety of projects for those starting or far into their consulting careers. There are high expectations for new associates, so the learning curve can be steep but results in developing a lot of skills early on.

PwC has pushed flexibility from the top down, and it shows. All of my teams have allowed for significant flexibility and trust team members to get their work done in the way that is near for them. That can include long periods of working from home, coming into the office later in the day, taking multiple coffee breaks, etc. The mindset is that if the work gets done and is of great quality, individuals should continue to be rewarded with as much flexibility as they need to succeed.

Colleagues genuinely seem to care about each other and I have made some life-long friends here. Very happy with my experience!
cons:
A lot of changes recently, including to our health benefits. Most employees are subject to a very high deductible that discourages trips to the doctor, which directly contradicts their current Be Well, Work Well initiative.

There was a period where they were hiring a lot from industry in FS Advisory, and some of those back office personnel are not strong performers in consulting.

headline: Truth
pros: Good for resume after 2-3 years with CA/CPA, easy to find another job.
cons:
Terrible office politics. Promotions based on sucking up to the partners upstairs, not based on your true objective performance as an individual. 

No Work/Life Balance - in busy season u'll be worked like a dog till midnight, with no overtime pay, just so that you can meet an arbitrary deadline that doesn't actually exist. 

At ratification meetings, you are compared against your peers, there is a tonne of backstabbing that occurs behind the scenes.

U frequently have 8 different managers asking 8 different things of u. You are always treated like a piece of meat thrown around between all the different managers who only care about their selfish selves and dont want to know about that fact that you have other client commitments.

U are always making up time - if u go on sick day or a volunterring activity, u are expected to make up for the hours u missed even though it was not your fault.

Staffing of jobs is terrible - the charge out rates are unrealistic, they are never recoverable from the client. Jobs are frequently understaffed just so that recovery can look better  for the partner on the job.

U are expected to work on weekends - personal life suffers massively, on top of this u don't get paid.

U are expected to contribute to the firm initiatives even though you are on dirt pay, and there is no incentive to drive the process.

headline: PwC SDC Bangalore(EGL & Exora) - Worst company - CMMI - Level 2
pros: Brand name of US company PwC( this is actually illusion, its kind of franchise and back office to do documentation work)
cons:
- SDC acts a very cheap offshore team for PwC USA which throws JUNK documentation work or some minute works to be done.

- They advertise themselves as PwC but not even one PwC policy is implemented and the entire culture is of Baring Point consultancy which was a junk company about to close and PwC acquired it.Though PwC acquired it, it is still being manged by baring point folks and it has its own HR and other policies which suck (Not PwC policies.).

- There is nothing PwC in PwC SDC except the name which they keep shouting brand brand brand

- No rewards, no outing parties.

- No transportation facility

- Managers are so dumb that they start hiring a technology person if client named a technology but once the project starts hired person will get to know that technology is no way related the project and client have used it in past. Manager will ask to work on the excel or whatever client ask even if is not related to your technology.

- Don't join this company if you have similar offer in any other IT company. This company don't have any career growth. Most of things are fake.

- Projects ? there are no projects here at all, All projects run in the USA and they will throw small tiny non challenging monotonous work here which will be our project! sorry sorry Task !

- Technology wise they don't know anything at all , they don't know the market because they can never get project themselves, that is there model : PwC US get projects , throws some junk work to PwC SDC bangalore. PwC SDC Bangalore can by itself cannot find projects , that is there working model.

-The directors - they are a laughing stock many of them don't know to even communicate properly in English.According to them you should work on anything then only you will grow.Complete idiots.

headline: PwC SDC, Bangalore.
pros: Good compensation, Work life balance(few projects), brand value

headline: Good place to try different types of consulting

Large variety of projects to try and get a feel for what you like (although this requires hardcore networking and some luck with timing). 

Big people and development focus - your bosses tend to be humans and not robots,  there's loads of development courses on offer and there is a focus on coaching during projects.
cons:
People try to turn you into a specialist very quickly. 

Promotion is often about who you know rather than what you know and how well you do something. 

Some managers are awful and should never manage people - but in my experience this is rare. 

Work life balance isnt bad but not as good as they make it out to be.

headline: A sinking ship
pros: Good large peer group when joined, nice, friendly and high calibre people to work with
cons: Terrible working culture, losing some clients and hence are trying to get rid of people, inevitably ended up with more people abandoning this sinking ship then expected. As a result, current staff was asked to work twice as much as before to cover. Bonus was nothing for 2 years and the majority of people are looking to exit. No care, appreciation or willingness to listen to staff from Partner levels. Not transparent culture, often people felt deceived by what was promised, such as the bonus pool was larger than previous years and somehow the majority ended up with less to little bonus.

headline: The best thing about PwC is how it looks on your CV.
pros: The best thing about PwC is how it looks on your CV.  PwC also gives its employees the ability to move around and experience other parts of the firm, or even in other countries.  It gives you the opportunity to work with various multi-national clients which means lots of travel opportunities.  There are numerous training courses to help you with your career development.
cons: It's a big company and you can feel a bit lost.  There are various unwritten rules which you need to figure out yourself.  There is a limited room for voicing your opinion.

headline: PwC - let's get real
pros: This is a big four auditing company guys! It feels super prestigious to work in a company like this. The building is also really great.

For some employees, every weekend and evening will be lost to working for PwC with little recognition.  The opportunity to learn real world skills is non-existent for extended time periods. The company has little awareness (despite claiming to), for basic human dignity, mental illness or the growth and development of many of its employees.

headline: Great network and employee development guidance

headline: Awful experience - don't do it.
pros: Exit opportunities, free CPA exam, free dinners. Not much in the grand scheme of things. For some reason, other employers value this place's employees, so you can capitalize on that good will. Leave as soon as possible.
cons:
Work life balance is horrible. You will never see friends or family. Busy season does not ever end - there is always more to do. It's bad all year.

Seniors wait until late in the day to give you work, ensuring you share in their misery into the wee hours.

The experience looks good on paper but being staffed on mega-engagements doing very specific  tasks leaves you with just a vague understanding of how specific software /work papers work, without any big picture context. You won't learn much unless you commit years of your life to the job, and doing so is social and familial suicide. You will find that after leaving you will have learned almost nothing useful.

My seniors were socially incompetent, cliquey, terrible at teaching and generally unhelpful - with a couple exceptions. They did not welcome new staff and were condescending and rude.

The healthcare benefits are terrible, especially if you have dependents. My wife and son qualified for state subsidized care, because UHC's coverage was so awful.

The pay is low. You can easily make just as much in an entry level staff accountant or internal auditor role at a private company. 

The flexibility promised by the recruiters and partners is a lie. Simply do not believe any of it. Their "flexibility" = being available via laptop 24/7 with no ability to get away from work.

headline: If you want a brand go for it

5. Work from home option
cons: 1. No cons at the firm level, now it depends on the project you fall in and your expectations. Eg. Someone who has been working in IT service companies, might not like it here for the way of working is not too process oriented. headline: Review on PwC SDC PVT LTD, Bangalore offshore cost center
pros:
-Brand Name
-Opportunity  to travel and work with clients
-Opportunity to learn specific domains
cons:
Low end technical work. 

The culture and values of the US entity seems to be missing in SDC

No work life balance.

Poor career coaching.

Non transparency in performance review process leads to stagnation and high attrition.

Managers can't make decisions.

Issue of stagnation as well.

There  is zero retention policy. 

No consistent travel policy.

A lot of travel.  

Some partners are very rude on offshore resources and put a lot of work pressure to meet deadlines. Quality is the last thing they talk about.

Managers are groomed into believe in theory X, people who some times work from home are monitored (lack of trust). 

A lot of job titles/levels in the organization structure. There are many managers, senior manages, associate directors and directors in the company. Some practices have multiple directors just
doing resource management bringing no value-add to the company. 
 
The company has become a white elephant with some of the managers and directors having lost their skill set are non-deploy-able/non-billable. 

There is a lot of opportunity to clean up the mess and evolve into lean culture.

headline: A great Big 4 Experience
pros: The Company offers great benefits to the employees. These include a large vacation balance, paid Firm closures, medical, dental, pension, 401(k), etc. With working in Non-Client Serving roles the Internal Firm Services departments are being strongly encouraged to telecommute. This allows our teams to work from home 2-3 days a week, which helps out immensely with work-life balance. Everyone in the Company works to be flexible in any way they can, whether you need to take time off or change your work schedule. Great core values and ethics.
cons: With working in the Non-Client Serving side of the company there was very limited earning potential and very hard to advance. This is understandable, as there are only "x" amount of back house roles needed when only "x" amount of market share is held. This just made advancing your career a lot longer than expected and kept you stuck in a salary range.

headline: Salaries and training excellent; "face time" and appraisals pointless.
pros: The prestige of working for a big four firm is very good for your CV. The training (study leave) was excellent and the pay grading for junior employees is transparent and fair, although some of the appraisal information seemed to be ill informed or unbalanced.
cons:
The blatant favouritism by middle managers towards junior employees who fawn, rather than excel.
"Face time" seemed to more important than intellect to many managers. I find it difficult to justify being at work when I am on top of my workload - I would rather be at home with my family than be seen to be working long hours needlessly.

2.Even after 3 months i left, waiting to receive my FnF which they claim will be given by 45 days
3. Even on my LWD they threatened me to go for client place, else they won't approve my resignation on Workday!
4.They will do litmus test to check where we are going, If we lie our face will turn red and they will understand that we are going to other BIG 4( Dono my manager did it n he told this)
5.They promised me that they will consider my request about the compensation, I followed up many times but they don keep promises which they make.
6.HR's doesn't have any power, Its strictly partner based.

headline: Amazing place to transform yourself, if you know what you want
pros: There is always somebody, somewhere, doing something you're passionate about. If you're lucky enough to find the team and get involved, there's so much you can get out of the PwC experience. I was not the happiest employee for the first few months, but was fortunate enough to find a group of people who were working on what I love. I wake up motivated every morning, believe it or not.
cons: Not all teams are alike, and finding that one niche is difficult, especially for new associates and senior associates. Some groups are more intense (I-banking-like), hierarchical, and don't treat you well, while others are more egalitarian, and understand the value of work-life balance. It truly depends on what you are doing, and with whom you're doing it.

headline: Poor Management (Middle East)
pros:
I worked for more than four years in the Middle East member firm, and the below are the Pros I learnt during the period of my employment:
The firm has good image among the people work in the same profession, others look up to people work (or worked) in PwC, It is an appealing brand and the benefits are within good standards (health insurance, life insurance,  employee loans, etc.)
cons:
The below are the Cons I learnt during the period of my employment:
Poor management which takes hasty decisions that impact the entire employees in the Middle East, unfriendly (arrogant) regionally placed management, lots of politics which negatively impacts the business and people, poor opportunities for growth (except for some).

cons: Disappointed to find that despite wanting to attract graduates from different backgrounds, PwC have not followed in the footsteps of firms such as KPMG and Grant Thornton, with regards to exam policy. The ACA exams had around 4,000 pages worth of technical material to learn around 30 years ago, now it's close to 10,000. I think it would help attract people from different backgrounds if the policy was more like KPMG's.

headline: A Good Place to Start

+ Cool & clean workspace, it's really comfortable

cons:
- Hard to reimburse (has to get director's & firm finance approval, and it's hard to get the finance ones)
- Half of the manager I worked with is not quite happy with "overtime approval", even though most of the works often come at the same time
- Social environment is quite...odd. It's good if you have your circle, but some people just talk behind your back if you go home at 5 even when you don't have any work for the day
- Can be toxic (sudden call @11pm without chat before even though it's weekend tomorrow & many blames here and there when it's not even your fault)
- Sometimes the teamwork is not efficient

headline: Great Place to Learn
pros:
You will work with very skilled and talented people on great clients.   Thus, it is a great place to learn and to develop as a professional.  Flexibility is available for those who are "on top of their game".  High performance is rewarded.

New tax staff are encouraged to rotate through various groups and are required to get diverse training.  This provides a broad skill set to build upon.  

You will attend a national training for a week every year and local trainings and online training is always available if you have the time.

The San Jose office is very oriented toward technology clients and venture capital clients.
cons:
Just the normal stuff you would expect working at a large client service organization --  resource managment issues and quite a bit of admin.  Lots of hours at times.

Clearly working for a big four accounting firm is nothing like working for the government.  If you are looking for a eight to five job then most of the time this isn't it.  Overtime is part of the deal but doesn't have to occur while you are at your desk.  Beyond office hours no one really cares if you are at your desk or not.  If you get your work done right and on schedule it will show up in your reviews and you'll be rewarded for it.

The work environment is young and full of energy. Due to the fact that busy season is in winter, in summer you can reach even 6 weeks of holidays. Its a Big 4 company: as a consequence, when you perform job interviews for other companies they usually appreciate this background. Its a great school.
cons: No work-life balance. Some senior managers, managers and partners are so addicted to job that some of them are always into the office, even late night on sundays or during holidays. I honestly think that these people do not have a family, friends or a relationship... they just care about the job. Emails and calls during night time and during holidays. Hours and hours spent in the office, always on saturdays, sometimes on sunday. Some people, if you leave at  7 p.m., ask you (but its a joke, of course) if you have a part-time contract This could be acceptable if you earn lot of money, but the average salary is very very very low... so, in my opinion, its not worth to sacrifice life for an amount of money for which you have to think 12 times before booking a restaurant.

headline: Satisfied but ready to move onto something new after 14 months on the job

I work in financial services an have seen all sorts of investments and derivative products.  There are many different types of jobs within the firm.  If you get tired of one job/team, you can easily request to be switched onto something new.
cons: Work your fingers to the bone.  No work life balance for first 3-4 years of work.  Busy season is miserable.  Lots of politics.  People judge you depending on which clients you work on.  Certain teams can become mini cultures.  The work can be mindnumbingly boring and repetitive.  In financial services at least, you rarely if ever communicate to the client as everything is automated.

cons:
1. For most of the employees, from entry-level staff to partner, there's not much work-life balance. Many people work overtime everyday and every weekend.
2. People are not treat equally. The evaluation and rewarding system is easily manipulated for office political purpose. People who work very hard are not appreciated. 
3. High turnover.
4. Compensation is not enough considering what the company takes from employees.

headline: Too much politics!
pros: Talented people. Professional atmosphere. Excellent work-life balance once you hit Manager level. Potential for fast promotions at junior levels (very slow once you are aiming for manager or above).
cons: Very political atmosphere. Leadership is not transparent. Bad people get promoted ahead of ones who deserve it. Long hours and lack of appreciation. High expectations of quality, and extreme pressures on achieving it in less hours every year as a result the culture and values the firm demonstrated over many years, had dropped dramatically and it all became about $$ and no longer about people. Hard to move between lines of services (once you do one, you pretty much stuck there). Pay is lower than elsewhere.

headline: Valuable Big 4 Experience...Not Good Long-term
pros: Since it's a large company, there are a lot of resources available to you, on the job and off it. The benefits are really good. You can gain a lot of valuable experience in a short amount of time.
cons: Competitive services industry gets translated to a very competitive work environment. The company stretches its employees to the limits, taking on unreasonable engagements and expecting high performance 110% of the time. Although this varies a lot by team, I think overall you are expected to put your personal life on hold any time a project requires your time at work. You are constantly evaluated in relation to your peers, even if it's an unfair comparison (you work on different kinds of projects, for example).

headline: Please avoid for your own welfare
pros: You will be able to meet a lot of people from different cultures.
cons:
1. Expatriates are rarely appreciated. Locals are always promoted regardless of the quality of work.
2. Favoritism is rampant.
3. During Covid-19, they only laid off expatriates but still hired locals. They said that it was based on performance but most of those laid-off employees just arrived in Malta few weeks before their termination.
4. During Covid-19, they always talk about efficiency and get the job done. They do not care about the employees' mental health.
5. They do not accept new ideas. They always rely on what was done before.
6. They always give the difficult tasks to expatriates.

headline: A place to BEGIN your career
pros:
Learn work ethic, organization, and stress management. A 9-5 would be a cakewalk after spending a year at PwC. 

The higher level employees within the organization tend to be very smart, driven, detail-oriented individuals. Lots can be learned from them.
cons:
The company has no regard for work/life balance and pushes its best employees the hardest. I spent an entire summer working 7 days/week and was not rewarded in any way. I am staffed on multiple clients and each team expects their respective work to be completed first. Overall, unless you love this lifestyle, not a place to stay for the long haul. 

As an associate, the work is labor-intensive and tedious. You will be asked to work on multiple clients and get the job done no matter the hour (I.e. Middle of the night/weekend/holiday)

headline: Risk Assurance
pros: If you are interested in a cross between IT and accounting, the Risk Assurance line of service is appealing as it exposes you to a lot of clients across a variety of industries. The trainings the firm provides are largely theoretical and not practical at all, but they also provide a good background knowledge.
cons: The 401(k) match isn't the best. You really have to be in charge of your career, in the sense that it pays to make friends with good managers and be booked on their projects. Otherwise, you'll be picked up on whatever project is available that no one else wanted to be on. The work itself can be incredibly mind-numbing, but for those generally interested in the work, I can see how it would be interesting. One aspect of certain engagements is that oftentimes you aren't involved in an engagement from start to finish, so you don't really get the whole "so what" of the engagement and any satisfaction from your output. Hours are truly random, there are a lot of downtimes, but too much of that will result in a poor review.

cons: Although there are a number of cultures, the french-speaking cultures are dominant.  In general, I found the French and Germans associated with people similar to them although the office does have a number of cultures represented.  I also found that decisions for promotions were very arbitrary (and often on cultural lines).

headline: As a new joiner
pros: There's many smart people here.
cons: Just started working. I don't know much yet.

headline: Great Place to Advance Your Career - High-Pressure Can be Taxing
pros:
You won't run out of growth opportunities. Generally, if you speak up for yourself and perform well, managers are willing to work with you to meet your needs/desires. You need to advocate for you needs, work-life balance, and advancement opportunities.

- Career Advancement
- Mentor-ship
- Learning Opportunities
- Exposure to Top Clients
cons:
Consulting can be a very high-pressure career. Team to team it will vary but it is not uncommon to end up with managers who expect work done at all costs. Including: constant travel to different cities (sometimes short-notice), long hours, mind-numbing tasks and pressure to do whatever is needed to keep the client happy. People tend to be generally helpful and friendly but in times of adversity, you'll see that everyone here is really looking out for themselves.

- High Pressure Environment
- Long Hours
- Constant Travel

headline: Manager
pros: Wonderful opportunities to work with some of the best clients and leaders in your chosen field of interest.  The talent and acumen of colleagues is also very impressive.
cons: Given its size, the company can be hugely bureaucratic, making seemingly easy tasks massively difficult to navigate.  The compensation system is equally vague and bureaucratic to maneuver.

headline: BEWARE!
pros:
Location of office.  
I'm sure there are good people somewhere in this firm, unfortunately, they didn't work in my group or HR.
cons:
Companies that use PwC as an auditor WILL NOT HIRE YOU after you've worked for PwC.  -even if you didn't serve as an auditor or work for any client!
Your next job search after PwC will take MUCH MUCH longer than it should because you waste colossal amounts of time talking to perspective employers only to find out that they can't hire you for "compliance" reasons because you worked for PwC.  
Many PwC lifers in senior roles that would be useless/unemployable elsewhere.  Retribution is alive & well here despite HRs efforts to pretend differently.
Not the place for a respected professional.

Shifts
cons:

Too much politics

headline: Beware Recruiting Lies
pros:
Great opportunities to interact with and network with high influence colleagues at the Firm and also at the clients. Exposure is significantly higher as a consultant than if you are employed by the clients directly.
Benefits of consulting are nice - expenses, happy hours, etc; as when you're generating revenue for your company they are more likely to treat you to these things.
Significant improvements have been made in the performance evaluation process and how employees are reviewed - less paperwork and more actual rating based on performance.
cons:
The Firm policy states that employees hired prior to the end of February are eligible for compensation increases (effective July 1) and bonus (paid ~October). Come June, I was informed that leadership made a decision to give zero increase or bonus to all employees who began after 1/1 in my practice (not Firm-wide). Deceiving recruiting and hiring practice.
Work/life balance can be rough at times, as working for clients can introduce a significantly higher level of urgency than working in industry.
Promotions are all politics. Could be a "Pro" if you consider yourself to be great at networking and "BS"ing, but beware that if you aren't at the top of the partners minds, you'll be glossed over.
Benefits suck, including 401k match - 25% of your contributions, capped at 1.5% if you contribute 6%

headline: Good firm, decent salary, long hours, no work-life balance, no benefits, and difficult to scale
pros:
PwC has a great brand name and good recognition in corporate America. This goes a long way in any client engagement. As a large firm, PwC also has a lot of resources at its disposal which is useful. You work with reasonably intelligent and hard working people, which always makes it easier.

PwC also has some senior leadership who are active in the day-to-day activities of engagements, which is good when they make firm-wide decisions that impact us.
cons:
Unlike most consulting firms, PwC does not have an up-or-out structure, which results in a lot of incompetent people who are perfectly happy to stay where they are at. This also means that there is no clear cut path to making Partner should you choose, and a lot more chaff than wheat.

Furthermore, while PwC pays well, their benefits (especially health and retirement plans) are pretty dismal. It is so poor that I am on my wife's healthcare plan as her spouse, which offers me more than PwC's own plan.

As a large firm with audit and tax divisions, PwC also comes with a lot of regulatory and other overhead, which impacts the amount of time you can spend on your actual engagements. Unlike the consulting divisions of other, similar companies (e.g. Deloitte), PwC's consulting analytics are all run by the engagement teams (e.g. expense reports, engagement margins etc). So, this adds additional overhead to already overworked teams.

headline: Audit associate
pros: Great exposure to different clients and great step for career. Company has a great brand and will be easy to find another job.
cons: Worked a lot of hours during busy season. It is a known item. The sad and unfair part is when some people have 2 to 3 busy seasons. That's messed up and unfair.

headline: Manager at Transaction Services
pros: Great collective, lots of projects, possible to do a fast track, good work-life balance, supportive office culture, very you start to get management experience (project and people management skills)
cons: Compensation is relatively low (you can easily double your salary if you decide to go to work in industry), after certain amount of projects the work could become repetitive and boring (financial due diligence is very similar process on each M&A deal)

headline: PwC Advisory is a great place to work
pros: I am constantly impressed by leadership, my colleagues and our new hires.  It is nice to be surrounded by committed, sharp, engaged individuals and if I were not I would have left long ago.  PwC is also very long-term focused rarely reducing staff (often at the expense of that years bonuses) but I would rather forgo a bonus so my colleagues can continue to have a job.  It also keeps us prepared for when times pick up unlike some of the other Big 4 who will go through lay-offs and then hire the same people back in a few months - that is ice cold.
cons: The travel can be brutal on work/life balance, but that is more a factor of being a Consultant and I'm not sure what PwC can do about that.  Often having a "local" client is worse - sure you go home every night but the commute can be upwards of 1.5 hours on top of already long days!

headline: Never work for the PWC SDC!
pros: None, the prestige that you would otherwise have is non-existent because PWC won't recognize you as an employee.
cons: Menial work. You are literally typing numbers off a spreadsheet into another program. A five year old could do this job. They are hiring people without degrees so they can pay less than the pittance of a salary they already provide. You will get zero useful experience and when you leave here after a number of years will be forced to take an entry level job like a new college graduate with no experience because of your lack of real accounting skills. Management refuses to let anyone transfer to the practice office. They will dangle a carrot of transfer, but once you are eligible they start making excuses. No one other than management has ever transferred from the SDC to the practice office.

headline: Great money and plenty of networking opportunities, but terrible work and culture.
pros: The prestige. You get to work with well-known clients. Great for resumes. If you WANT to play the game and sip the Kool Aid you can get pretty far! Also, if you're just a dude who needs to make money to provide for himself and his loved ones and think you can handle the BS of working Big 4, then this will be a nice, stable job for you, and I respect that!
cons: Management is disconnected from reality. They don't put in enough effort to get to know their Associates, relate to them, and appreciate them. Hardly ever see management. They're just traveling 95% of the time and only checking in once a week to make sure you're working your behind off. All social interactions are transactional. Terrible hours. Mentally and emotionally taxing. Too competitive of a culture. It's all about image. SO superficial.

headline: Working at PwC- My experience
pros:
You get to learn a lot
Great avenue for growth and development career wise
Associations with peer group.
Good brand and reputation- People tend to give you a lot of respect in the professional world.
Working environment could be fun at times. 
All in all not the best place to be, but not the worst by a long shot either.
cons:
No work life balance most times
Pressure filled and stressful
Favoritism and some politics involve to progress past a certain level.
Boring and repetitive (Audit & Assurance)
Pay is not commiserate with the work you do.
No overtime pay  
Team structure is never constant, so you have to adapt each time on different teams which can be very frustrating at times.

headline: Poor Management
pros: It's a Big 4. You may have good learning and working experience if you're lucky and have a good manager and team.
cons: The management may feel sorry for you but they don't really care about your career and life.  They would hire external employees instead of promoting good employees internally.  I don't think the firm knows how to increase employee morale and it could be very disorganized. Lots of red tape that prevent good business decision-making. They give out a chocolate bar to some employees who worked the most overtime in the previous week, while another Big 4 provides unlimited snack throughout the day. Really? Working from home may hinder your career even though the firm keeps advertising it has flexible work arrangement. One's experience varies widely depending on the team but most of the time, it could be disappointing.

headline: An old school auditor duckling that so badly wants to be viewed as the swan.
pros:
Opportunity to work with very intelligent people and work in an organization that is far more than an accounting firm. PwC has gone through it's own share of growing pains and has spun off and then reinvested in a variety of businesses over the years and now that the non-compete with IBM has expired their Advisory practice is fully able to serve clients the way that they want to. This is an extremely exciting time to be a part of this business because the PwC reputation is extremely valuable globally and most of the clients are large multi-nationals. There is a heavy commitment to PwC People and while you work around the clock like a dog, there is a shared respect and support. Similar to living in New York, you never know how supportive your neighbors are until there is a crisis but when there is, the firm stands behind you. 

Strong commitment to community service.
cons:
It is by no means perfect, it is often described as Investment Banking hours at accounting wages. There is still a lot the firm needs to do to walk the talk and drink it's own very valubale advice it provides to its clients. There are two types of people at PwC, partners and those waiting to leave. IFS and support roles are simply never as valued as client facing roles and you will not make partner and therefore will never reap the true rewards of your work if you find yourself in that role. IFS people must be satisfied being a servant but never a knight. 

On the client facing side it is very much a deliverable mentality. These are people who are really good at working hard and turning work in on time, but many lack the relationship skills to look past the work product to truly partner with their clients to anticipate their issues and become fully invested in the success of their clients. Subject matter expertise is never a problem, communicating and articulating issues in a way that non-PwC people understand is always underestimated and extremely valuable when done right.

Slow to move - cannon on an ant. Th firm has so many layers of adminstrative beuarocracy that common sense can often take a back seat to policy without purpose. There are great and innovative and creative people who get frustrated and leave because they focus on results and the method is a secondary concern. This is where its history of being an auditor can hinder growth and creativity. Running a business consulting practice which includes tax consulting and transaction services like you do an audit practice simply does not make sense. Again, the firm would not advise its clients to do this but can't seem to get out of its own way.

Can't invest in ANYTHING! Forget your personal portfolio. Working for the firm that audits most of the financial services and fortune 100's means you are precluded from investing in pretty much everything unless you spend all of your free time working through independence issues.

headline: Interned to Full Time
pros: Great opportunities to learn, work with smart people in a community that is inclusive and supportive. A big thing PwC pushes is "Be Well, Work Well" which helps some with work-life balance as they understand the strain we are managing. Personally, the mantra of PwC is something I love - "Our purpose is to solve complex problems and promote trust in society." They don't just put that on a billboard in the office, it feels like something PwC is driven and focused on doing which makes me a proud employee.
cons: Challenging work, you have to be a self motivator, willing to learn and apply yourself. Work-life balance can be difficult to manage. I've found that success is found through a sink or swim approach. You have to get up and volunteer to get things done and form relationships that will want to work with you in the future. There are tons of resources and support, you just have to be proactive in utilizing them. I often dream of retirement and or changing jobs to something less demanding but I feel the personal growth and professional experience is worth it.

headline: Great Benefits at PwC!
pros: All benefits start on the first day of employment. Most managers are very supportive of people needing time off for family leave, even in unexpected emergencies, like death of loved one.  The firm puts a percentage of your income into a retirement plan, in addition to salary. Free annual physical at a highly professional healthcare facility. Chances to join groups to give back to society: Belize trips to help educate kids, for example.  They encourage participation in charity.
cons: They use the common performance review model where you are rated on a scale of 1-5, 1 meaning superior, usually resulting in a promotion and significant raise, and 5 meaning termination.  But Partners and Directors on the ARC Committee responsible for approving a Director's choice of rating for employees may not have any work experience with the employee being rated, which in my opinion indicates a tight suppression of raises, especially for roles in support-related positions like HR.There are only so many 1s and 2s available, so not everyone in a given department can be a 1 or a 2, which points to the systemic problem in our country wherein salaries have remained basically flat for the past 30 years. This method also puts you in direct competition with your team members, and at times, in my opinion, can decrease productivity and morale.

headline: Great training for the individual (with soul-crushing focus on billable hours), peculiar visions by leadership
pros: - for 20-somethings in their first job, you will get great training in technical skills, while also learning to work really hard and do high-quality work
cons:
- You will learn to dread the unenviable tug of war between "keep your billable hours as high as possible" and "try not to bill too many hours to this client"

- You will look at the existing contracts (back in 2011, I remember Partner rates at $400-500/hour) and you will learn how clients chose a competitor for the bid, and you will wonder why they cannot realize that their rates are too high

- You will sit in one of the town hall meetings (ok, this was back in 2006) and you will hear the leadership exult, "last year was our BEST YEAR EVER ... so this year, we are looking to BEAT THAT!" and you will wonder how this seems sustainable. But you are 23, so you keep your mouth shut. And then you watch as people are laid off, because they were behind budget. But the budget was built on stupid goals.

- You do work you are not qualified to do, because your partner is desperate for any work.

headline: If you enjoy the work, a great company
pros: Career progression is very structured, which ensures you always know where you stand, what is next, and what needs to be done to achieve the next level. This also permits you to do some future life planning, as you generally know what level you can make it to in X years, so long as you perform at or above average.
cons: Staffing seems to be a continuous problem that never really gets resolved. Staff shortages lead to even more overworked staff, which is not a great reward for the good staff that stays. This leads to good staff leaving, and a vicious cycle. From my observations over several years plus , and based on public accounting history, this is not a new problem, as so a logical conclusion is the company also knows this and does not really mind, despite what HR may say.

headline: PwC culture
pros: PwC culture is inclusive, diverse, and forward looking. They are constantly looking for ways to be on the cutting edge of best places to work from a work environment, culture, and flexibility perspective, which comes from both the global chairman Bob Moritz and the new US chairman, Tim Ryan.
cons: Despite preaching partnership, as with most Big 4 firms, revenue accounting for partners does not align with teaming - it aligns whose name is on the code, despite who contributed to the ultimate signed engagement letter. Performance reviews now come almost exclusively from partners, which diminishes input from managers, who work with staff more closely on a day-to-day basis.

headline: Many opportunities for learning and career development but getting too big
pros: First off, it really dependents on the line of service (Audit, Tax, Advisory or IFS) and even then, the groups and/or offices within these lines.  Two people will have totally different experiences based on this.  I worked in Advisory, which has gone through a lot of changes in the past 5 years.  It's growing quickly, much of it by acquisition and the strategy seems to change frequently.  The work is hard and the hours unpredictable.  It can be quite easy between projects but then there is the pressure that you're not "chargeable".  You don't want to be in that position for very long or you'll have a target on your head.  The co-workers are top notch and you learn a lot from each other.  Benefits are good.  You're treated like a professional and expected to act like one.  The firm is very concerned with its reputation and looks at you as an extension of their brand.  Many merit-based opportunities for promotion.
cons: While there are many opportunities for professional growth, you don't really have much control over where.  It really depends on the projects you're on and frankly, PwC doesn't exactly do the sexiest types of consulting work.  Much of their focus is improving operations, getting companies out of a crisis or some sort of reporting improvements.  There are often mixed signals between the firm leadership's position on things and how partners actually execute it.  That's not to say most partners aren't working just as hard as the staff, it's just that they have to make clients happy, make staff happy and make the firm lots of money and those three things are pretty hard to reconcile.

I wonder how much time Mr. Director has... Micromanagement apart, he seems to be Omnipotent (take a bow, all ye mortals!). I wish I could give a minus rating to PwC SDC on Glassdoor.

headline: Great education/work experience, long hours
pros: If you are in accounting and want to get the most well rounded work experience from the start, PwC is the place to go.  The Company is very supportive of its staff in providing ample vacation and decent benefits, great technical resources, experienced/smart people, opportunities for transfer domestically or short tours (2 years) abroad.  This is a great place to start your career given that you go into a company to audit it/do their taxes and top management has to explain to you what they are doing.  Great learning experience.  There is a lot of hierarchy in the Company; however, most of the partners do take an interest in their staff and are supportive in their interests.
cons: Although the vacation benefits are fantastic (5 weeks after a year I believe), it is difficult to sometimes take that vacation as well as totally disconnect while on vacation.  The hours on this job are like a rollercoaster.  During January - March, you are expected to give up your life for this job.  It is very difficult to achieve work life balance, especially during that time of year.  On the flip side, May - August, is usually not that bad, hours will usually be light, unless you have an off-year-end client.  Travel is really a mixed bag, depending on what clients you are assigned, but it can be significant.  Overall, you have to take the good with the bad and the experience starting out is invaluable.

headline: PwC, a great place to build a network.
pros: PwC was good at teaching people a way of analytically thinking for those who wanted to learn.
cons: There was sometimes pressure to eat your hours in order to meet budgets.  Additionally, there were some promotions which I did not feel were earned.

headline: PwC review

headline: CMAAS
pros: Good amount of very smart people. Very good name brand for the resume. Overall firm as a whole is not afraid of change and can pivot quickly for its size.
cons: Travel is required at the drop of a hat. Some managers and directors can really lack management skills. Charged out at $300 an hour and see 1/10th of that. Long term assignments can restrict learning and can pigeonhole your career to very specific and nuanced topics. Selling work and getting more chargeable time means creating issues at clients. Pay is only 5% more than audit and hours are considerably worse (no busy season, just projects).

headline: I would like a life
pros: Advancement, Learning Ops, Hardworking Staff, Community Oriented.  THe slow periods are very slow which allows for long vacations or CPA studying
cons: Lack of Worklife Balance, Long Hours.   The hours can be very long during busy season with little sleep even on the weekends.  This in the New York office so it may be different else where. If you are not into working long hours for periods of the year then this is not the place for you. Very hard to study for the CPA while working tons of hours.  Get your CPA before you start at PWC or else it will be quite hard.

headline: A lot of opportunities, long working hours, low salary and benefits, unfair and incompetent management .
pros:
this review is based on my experience in PWC Azerbaijan for 2 years. As the office is pretty small there is always not enough resources and employees are made to do jobs above their required experience level which makes the employee to improve quickly. 
There are a lot of opportunities as any Big4 brand is great addition to CV and working in such company makes it easier to build relationships with important people.
cons:
Working hours can be extremely long. Management does not care about the happiness of employees and exploit them by allocating a lot of work (even their own). Audit associates can be in required to deliver couple projects simultaneously. 
Overtime is not paid and salaries are low compared to other offices in neighbouring countries. Annual bonus (for associates) (is so low that, it) is a joke.
Senior Management in PWC is incompetent and very unreasonable when it comes to performance reviews and promotions. As the turnover is high, bright employees leave for better opportunities, leaving behind unreasonable and incompetent management. 
PwC offers global mobility opportunities but the management is very keen on to block employees attending such programs by bringing up funny reasons.

headline: A Federation of Companies
pros: PwC brings together a variety of experts from various fields.  These "experts" are positioend as partners and expected to grow the business in their designated capability area.  This allows for a very wide range of solution offerings and an ever-growing need for new capacity and skills.
cons: Each partner has their revenue target.  Compensation is based on individual performance and performance of their team.  In some cases, that performance disregards the firm's bigger/broader goals.

headline: Avoid PwC Saratoga (HR analytics consulting) at all costs
pros: Overall reputation of company and training opportunities.  There are a lot of locations so you can conceivably transfer between offices.  I'm noticing a lot of job postings for this group so am posting this as a public service announcement.
cons: Everything else...the PwC Saratoga group is horribly run and in many cases psychologically abuses employees.  The culture is driven by one of the partners, who takes advantage of employees and is not fully honest with clients with the objective of maximizing profits at all costs.  Saratoga in its earlier incarnation (pre-PwC) was a thought leader in HR analytics, not so any more, so don't expect that the role will take you very far externally.  I would only wish a job with this group to my worst enemy.

headline: PwC

headline: Audit Associate
pros: Huge company, has a lot of "pull", prestige, power, great people, and great clients.  The firm loves to work hard but also play hard.  You will not skimp on team events and other celebratory events.  I genuinely think that the company works hard to please the people who work for them.
cons: Hours can be tough, some people find the work stressful, and pretty unhealthy at times.  Similar to any other office job, you sit at a computer, staring at a screen for hours on end, looking forward to stuffing your face with the highest calorie item on the dinner menu that the company pays for.  So you have to actively find ways to stay fit.  Can end up eating most of your life.  Work life balance is still a hot topic.

pros: You will have the opportunity to be on many projects that will challenge your skill set
cons: If you were not considered a star it could be hard to find work, and you will find yourself on any type of project. Also this plays a role with utilization if you are not on a project.

headline: The 600+ member Advanced Risk & Compliance Analytics (ARCA) group in PwC is full of manipulative and arrogant people.
pros: They pay well and the pros end here! Honestly I don't have anything else to say about my experience with PwC. The brand name looks good on the resume while interviewing for other firms but within the firm, especially the ARCA group, my experience has been very bad. The only motivation I get here is a good paycheck.
cons:
You cannot trust people in ARCA. 

People higher up in the role think too highly of themselves and don't respond to juniors.

Lot of gender discrimination seen against men in ARCA group. Directors are more likely to get beautiful females in their teams. 

The ARCA group is a big group of dirty politics! There is no motivation for career growth unless you want to be sycophant to certain people in the firm.

headline: Good policies but unrealistic

headline: Great opportunity to learn
pros: Good team spirit. A lot of very challenging opportunities. Extremely varied scope of work in terms of content as well as in terms of targeted industries. The quality of the management and peers also make it an enjoyable working environment.
cons: The flip side of the coin : the scale doesn't allow for closer interaction. Also office politics tend to be time consuming. The higher on the ladder, the more distracting it becomes.

cons: Poor work-life balance marketed as flexibility. Inconsistent performance evaluation scale which seems to always be a moving target. Leadership seems to have a mentality of what have you done for me lately.  Career development is lack luster even though tremendous investment has been made to improve coaching and performance management.

headline: Very difficult place to work
pros: If you find a good team or manager or partner to work with, then you will be ok. The company has some great people.
cons: If you get stuck with bad managers or a bad team, they will blame it on you and make it your fault. The way the company works is you are ranked based on how much work you do, except you have to find the work yourself. LOTS of politics involved that aren't in your control.

headline: Great Work-Life Balance
pros: PwC really cares its employees

headline: Come for the people, stay because you're too tired to leave
pros:
The sheer amount of work you are required to complete in an insanely short amount of time really makes you a very competent worker. Never before did I imagine I could work 16 hours straight for 30+ days (and that wasn't even busy season).
Before COVID, the happy hours and company-sponsored parties and events were great.
There's a set career path and clear milestones.
I believe that senior management really does care about humanity on a macro scale. 
The people who work there are generally cool people.
cons:
People above you are stressed, and so they take it out on you.
The compensation is not high enough for the amount of work you are required to do. 
There is a huge push towards automation, except that all the time-savings due to technology are not passed on to the audit team, rather they are used to squeeze even more value and effort out of the team. As long as the bottom line is the focus, the human capital is going to become more and more drained and exhausted.
The working hours are insane.
The toll on your mental health.
The toll on your physical health.
Some managers are stressed and angry, and they take it out on you, and it can be a very toxic work environment.
I could go on but it would be getting repetitive.

headline: Some pros, some cons, and a lot of red tape
pros:
- 22 vacation days a year
- Talented employees and team members
- Excellent parental leave policy (3 weeks fully paid for new fathers, 6 weeks fully paid for adoptive parents, doesn't come out of vaction balance).
- Great brand recognition/resume builder
cons:
-Low pay. 
-Leadership don't seem to be on the same page as one another, which causes a lot of confusion and chaos downstream.  
-Process, Process, Process.  Congress has less red tape.
-IFS are second class citizens - not unusual for professional services companies but still a con.  
-or teams with bonuses, lunch, gift cards,etc
-Very politcally correct environment.
 
Prior to the reorg, this was a fantastic place to work with career opportunities, strong teams, and great morale.  Since then, it has become just a job.

headline: Great first out-of-college job for the experience, but be mindful of the disastrous office politics.
pros:
Pros:
- decent pay for Columbia area (but not great)
- 3 weeks vacation and unlimited sick time
- "flex" Fridays and work-life balance 
- non monetary career development 
- you'll gain lots of different skills while working here
- getting PwC on your resume is huge
cons:
Cons:
- pay is only based on the Columbia area, so many employees leave for higher paying jobs in larger cities
- poor bonus structure. Less than 2% raise and bonus per year
- the MD (Norm) has unrealistic and abstract expectations. It's his way or no way.
- communication between project leaders (who are usually from core) and the Columbia leadership is nonexistent. Even if the project leaders think you do a great job, if Norm doesn't, you will not get a raise
- reinvestment activities (which are basically extracurricular activities outside of 40 hours) are expected in order to get ahead. If you don't, you will just be "average" in Norm's mind and not get promoted

headline: If you are set on the big 4, pick another firm
pros:
- Great place to have on your resume.
- Relatively easy to get hired.
- Little prior knowledge needed (they offer a lot of trainings )
- Promotion options available, regardless of talent (PWC usually promotes associates to senior associates after 3 years and senior associates to managers after an additional 3 years. This is assuming you get okay reviews, but realistically reviews mean nothing because you get a normal review unless you are in the top ten percent or the bottom ten)
- Easy behavioral question based interviews.
cons:
- It is like being in high school ( the partners are treated as deity and should they condescend to your level than you should be so lucky. Also you have to spend any free time you might have kissing up to those above you.
- They don't care about their employees (to them you are a number and if your utilization rate is lower than they think it should be you are inefficient)
- Low pay for long hours
- No work life balance
- Don't believe what they tell you in the recruiting process, most of the time the people that they send to do the recruiting on college campuses don't know what they are talking about. 

If you are just going to work there to get the big name, go to one of the other big 4 they usually promote faster.

I value experience and diversity of engagements & clients rather than being Manager, Senior Manager etc. The framework is rubbish.

Everyone else around you will be working a lot, and this never changes as you move up the ladder, so you have to be prepared to make the job the primary focus of your life. They're actively trying to promote work-life balance, and doing a decent job, but the culture is so ingrained at this point that it will never be a relaxed 9-5 type of environment.
