headline: Good culture
pros: Good building,  culture,  coaching
cons: Long hours during peak season

headline: I don't know one person who enjoys this job
pros:
- Free Bagels during busy season
- New floor plan
- Majority of people are nice/all suffering through the same thing
- monthly $100 Student loan payments
cons:
- No work/life balance, expect 12-14 hour days and when that ends it's still 10 on average
- HR does not care for company policy
- If you show interest in other areas, don't expect to be moved for at least a year. Even if it's just internally.
- Small teams have tight budgets (less or no team outings, forced to eat hours, may not be able to charge dinner/ubers)
-Disconnected partners

If you're looking for a job where no matter what you do you won't get fired, take this one. It is so short staffed they can't do anything. Additionally, expect insanely long hours and weekends. When the hours do finally die down you are still getting out at 6 or 7. This job will take a lot out of you. Be cautious before joining and ask if you want to pigeon-hole yourself into this field/type of work. Also, the amount of Kool-Aid everyone forces down your throat is unreal, then you join and it couldn't be more reversed.

headline: Great people, rich partners, overworked staff
pros: Good reputation, strict hiring process has value when moving to the next job. Good food around, coffee machines etc. Beautiful offices. Staff were motivated intellectuals.
cons: Unpaid overtime, I knew teams that worked till midnight at least 1-2 weeks per month. Parking in the city is expensive, only partners got free parking in the building.

headline: Good place to start
pros: PWC is a great place to cut your teeth and get your career started. I learned alot and developed a great work ethic.
cons: You have to manage your career at PWC. It sounds cliche but, it is what you make of it. If you wait for opportunity to come to you, this is not the place for you.

headline: Challenging and Rewarding Place To Work
pros: Fast paced environment with a steep learning curve. Clear progression plan with increasing opportunities. Global company with opportunities to move internationally.
cons: Workloads are not evenly allocated. If you are a strong performer you take on more work than is feasible, causing unnecessary stress. People care about you, however, it is also a business.

headline: PwC
pros: L&D opportunities for employees if you could find the time

headline: Interesting for a short to mid-term experience

headline: Its good if you know the trade else its a nightmare
pros:
1. PwC is a LLP company owned by partners - the partners are the powerhouse and the company revolves around them if you are in a partner's good book - sky is the limit - I have seen colleagues getting 30% salary hike double promotion and other perks
2. Big Four has its own advantage for further employment - other companies recognize and appreciate the experience
cons:
1. Partners are powerhouse - if your are not in their good books then either you dont exist or your life in pwc is short lived - a general trend in these companies is that people either stay 10-15 years or 2 years (first year default rating second year bad rating)
2. Big fours dont have bench - so you are supposed to work on 2 projects simultaneously with 100 % billing in each - minimum because you should be suprised to see people working on 5 projects at the same time - and I dont mean engagement - I mean full fledged development testing work
2. Partners are the powerhouse - and hence no process - I dont know why they have a human resource department because they are pretty much non existent at line level
3. You get to work on open source only - since buying products afftect project margins 
4. If you travel onsite you will be given a daily per diem - accomodation and travel costs only - per-diem is so low you would eventually spend from your pocket if you smoke or drink
5. Rating charts goes to the partners - if you are on good books you get good ratings if you dont exist you get average if you are on bad books you get bad rating 
6. rating 4 puts you in performance improvement program where you will be asked to bring in projects and revenues in a span of 2 months (manager onward everyone is fired in this manner)
7. No additional perks - travel is not provided - food is average and 50% subsidized
8 work life balance sucks - your clients will beg you to go to sleep and take a break/rest - but if you work on 5 projects sleep rest family kids are out of question
9. Not good for freshers - you will get training on floor - which in itself is a very bad concept

headline: PwC Transaction Services...an ok place to spend 4 years
pros: Working at a Big 4 based consulting group (e.g., Transaction Services aka TS) will help you develop a 'jack of all trades' skill set. Generally speaking most people learn & develop the following after ~5 years: a team-based attitude, strong accounting skills, sharp financial analysis skills, above average writing skills, and public speaking/presentation abilities. If one wants to make it to Sr Mgr/Director or Partner than being able to accumulate friends at that Partner level is paramount. At some point politics/bureaucratic tendencies become just as important as the other required skills.
cons: Generally speaking working at a Big Four consulting group like PwC TS can pigeonhole you should you want to transition into the more sophisticated areas of finance that include banking, trading, private equity and/or equity research. Additionally the more junior you are the less fair your pay will be; partially this is offset by robust amounts of vacation you will receive. Do not expect a good bonus; it can happen but the bonus mentality in Big Four firms barely rewards the younger staff in proportion to the effort they contribute. Lastly due to nature of client service the requirement to work long hours is typically inevitable at some point...be prepared to put your time in as you work your way up.

cons:

Hiring engineers for non-technical roles which do not require a high school degree.

headline: GRC Tech. partner constantly looked down the subordinates.
pros: Lesson-Learned.  I had a chance to observe that they lost clients and learned the reasons.
cons: We were looked down by the partner.  We were always reminded of that we do not have a credibility.  We observed that the consultants tell the clients the best practice without a deep industry experience, but for their telling/advising the best practice, the IFS (internal firm services) does not follow this.  So, we learned that to say the best practice to clients or prospects is easy, but they cannot demonstrate it by themselves.  Good learning opportunity

headline: Former Risk Assurance  Internal Audit Senior
pros: PwC has a lot of brand recognition within the Accounting / Finance world. That said, if you work in Assurance, put in 2-3 years and leverage your experience for a career with a better trajectory / hours / culture / work life balance (e.g. transaction advisory, equity analyst roles).
cons:
I worked within the Chicago Internal Audit Practice at PwC for a significant period of time and cannot imagine a more terrible way to waste away my 20s. I would describe the culture within the practice at best as "toxic". Typically, the more tenured individuals within the practice are the most difficult and least enjoyable to work with; Partners and Directors have little interest in your development or interests (e.g. transferring to a different line of service) and are often rude.  At times, this particular practice felt like a sorority where gossip rather than performance prevailed. 

Unless you are working on a marquee client or for a well respected Manager / Director, it is not uncommon for you to get lost in the fold and receive mediocre ratings thru the duration of your employment. Finally, as associates, the bulk of the work you will be performing is Sarbanes Oxley Compliance testing, which is essentially a gigantic compliance exercise that adds little no value.

If you're intelligent, sociable, eager to learn / work, want  to build-up your business acumen and develop tangible skills, look elsewhere!

cons: As with big corporations you can get lost in the shuffle.  Was discouraged by some of the actions taken place at the National HQ. headline: Smart, friendly colleagues, lots of opportunities, inclusive culture (for the most part)
pros:

Leader (Tim Ryan) who tries to create a culture of diversity and acceptance of everyone
Possibility of interesting work (not always the case, but at least almost every project is challenging in some new way)
cons:
Like at any consulting firm, requires extra work (“reinvest”) for which you don’t get any billable hours
White male boys’ club culture in certain areas/practices that still reigns supreme and makes women and minorities leave and feel unwelcome
Minimal in-person training opportunities
Lots of pressure to use digital tools for everything and anything, which is like finding a nail for a hammer even when it doesn’t make sense

headline: Private Sector Operations Consulting - Politics not hard work
pros: Some people are less interested in politics and have a more genuine interest in doing a good job.
cons: In the Private Sector Operations Consulting practice, more people are interested in politics and baseless promotions rather than hard work and developing oneself professionally.  This behaviour is supported by a phony leadership team with an approach to people management that does not reward hard work and capable people but rather those who play the game well. It is widely accepted that the leadership team plays favourites and that the end-of-year performance reviews are popularity contests.  Wide-spread discontent is evidenced by low levels of morale and high staff turnover.

cons: Structure is too rigid, managers lack a lot on the leadership aspect and mostly micromanage employees, some also lack on knowledge. cons: With all of the above in mind, you work for everything you get. Hours are long. Stress is high. You will pulled in many directions at the same time and told that each one is top priority. Time management and thick skin are a must.

headline: The Mass Absorbs the Talent, But Vestiges of Possibility Remain
pros:
- The people you meet who are interesting are very interesting, sincere, and thoughtful
- Great diversity in the types of projects you can take on
- "Any work you do is worth 2-3X the same duration spent in Industry"
cons:
- Many stressed, tired middle-managers trying to make partner, who are liable to make your own life equivalently stressful
- While projects are diverse, many are very boring, and strictly analytical/process-oriented -- if you're looking for real strategic discussions, rather than tactics, or perhaps a blend of different skillsets -- this isn't the job for you. The whole idea is to create something that can be copied and pasted for a future client -- intelligent customization is off the table
- Try calculating your salary by the hour, and looking at your work-life balance, and THEN compare to "Industry"
- Hugely hierarchal -- to be expected, but hardly optimal -- just another restatement of the generality and standardness of policy here. It's all about "covering all bases," not trying to do anything perfect.

If you report anything against your manager or Director, it will for sure be remembered and retaliation comes back at you in different form that you may not expect. As long as you obey to them its good for your survival. Probably same with any employer, in that sense.

headline: Proceed with Caution
pros:
Benefits
Vacation Time
Opportunity for Training and Certifications
Some opportunity to move into a lateral position
Flex Time - but depends on your boss
Bonus (before the economic slowdown it was good)
cons:
Senior Management sets unrealistic goals

Poor Leadership which creates a poor culture

Performance Appraisal Process is subjective - you can go the whole year, get great feedback forms, then get a bad overall review.  

Cut Throat - performance system pits peers against one another.  Have a culture where everyone is out for themselves.  They preach teamwork but since the performance system compares you to your peers people are less likely to share knowledge and truly work as a team. 

Politics - if you form alliances and kiss up, you can move up.  Every decision is rooted in some politics - they don't choose the path that is most benefical, they choose the one that is most popular for their personal career advancement.

Lack of advancement opportunity - they tell you to take control of your career and even if you get great ratings, promotions are hard to come by (unless you join as an associate or senior associate) 

Leadership is arrogant and treats staff like slaves.  They preach worklife/balance but if you go on vacation and they need you, your expected to work. Good managers would ensure you had a backup so you can enjoy your vacation - it's a benefit after all.  

PwC  = People Working Constantly

Internal processes - it is impossible to get anything done. So much red tape even for the simplest of requests.  The left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.

A TON of offshoring - if you take an offer there be prepared to be let go in the near future.  They are offshoring in every department and line of service - even parts of the audit practice (although I have not heard of a single partner that had his job sent overseas)

Most of the management is poor but it depends on who your boss is.  I had 7 bosses during my tenure and I can honestly say I only had 2 good ones - and they both quit.

headline: Assurance Associate
pros:
- Great exposure to industries and the biggest clients in the economy, no matter where you are globally
- Best way to start your career as the experience you gain from working with different staff members and clients on various engagements and the type of work you do (intense workload and long stressful hours) will prepare you for any type of work environment which you will encounter later on in life.
- The people who you work with are extremely intelligent and knowledgeable.
- Training and coaching programmes are amongst the best of all the accounting firms
- Opportunities to move to other offices or go on global secondments
- Having the experience and the PwC brand on your CV will help you no matter where you go, as there is a global standard of the highest quality and excellence which is recognised by recruiters
cons:
- Long stressful hours with little pay and no overtime.
- Working in an environment in which you constantly feel threatened or pressured, as the smallest offset could make you get a bad rating on an audit or not get the over time pay which you had initially agreed on with the manager.
- Being at the mercy of all your managers and seniors as your ratings are dependent on how they feel about you and if they are unhappy or in a bad mood, they could rate you badly and it will go on your company record.
- Underappreciated staff and a resultant high turnover, which further upsets clients because the audit teams keep changing.
- Too much red tape with every internal process which has to be conducted.
- High level of hierarchy and partners who constantly act like they are too good to speak to you and they dont care about your future or your career

headline: Recommended for people who are pursuing a career in the accounting industry
pros: Recognised, Staff development focused, working with similar age group colleagues
cons: Long working hours, overly fierce competition

headline: Enjoyable

headline: Good starting point of your career path, but not the destination for your long-term development.
pros: Great opportunities to understand different business models in various industries. Foreseeable career development in the first five years, If you are doing OK, the firm would promote you each year from A2 to SA1, which means your salary would increase 20% or more each year. Very professional life for a fresh graduate, you have opportunities to work with fortune 500 companies, to understand different business, to travel to different places, to enjoy your life with your teammates. Just like have another 5 years college life. Moreover, PwC integrates global learning and training resources for different level employees, you would have high quality training programs for your career development.
cons: First, no good life/work balance. Sometimes have to work more than 90 hours per week. Especially during the peak season and IPO projects. There are is almost no room for your personal life. Second, Top management don't have competency to manage the fast growing firm. They are auditors and good leader for a team, but definitely not a good leaders for a group or firm.  When comparing with other top companies in the world, the efficiency and the style of management in PwC can not match its well-known brand. Most of time, associates and managers don't like their boss-- Partners.

headline: Loved my time there

- As with all audit jobs, long hours are expected. Work-life balance is non-existent during the peak period.
- Portfolio allocated may cause one to have a peak period that lasts 9 months.
- Lack of staffs might at times require managers to roll up their sleeves to get the job done.

4)  You do the same stuff that any typical Indian IT company would do and yet you would be given a feeling that you are doing something great.

headline: Almost forget why I left...do I dare say I miss it?
pros:
- Great team environment
- Upward mobility with a clear career path forward
- Strong focus on learning and development
- Focus on feedback and improvement
- Large firm with offices almost everywhere you want to be in the United States or International
- A lot of smart people
- Great benefits - vacation, pay, maternity/paternity leave
- The brand is everything
cons:
- Long hours during busy season - but that's a given
- Difficult to move around to different engagements or different line of service despite having a plethora of opportunities available
- Would rather work their best people to the ground and drive them out rather than work with them to improve their quality of life
- Giving your best and doing your job is not enough - constant pressure to go above and beyond
- Lacking in resources at times to keep margins 
-

headline: Great place to learn, terrible place for career progression
pros:
- Some of your coworkers will become your closest friends. I exited into the industry and my closest friends till this day are the ones I made during my time at PwC
- You will learn a lot of soft skills that a lot of people in the industry do not possess including stress management, communication, and prioritizing
- Most people I encountered were intellectually curious and hard working, which not everyone in the industry is like that
cons:
- Your managers are not really invested in your career progression unless you are an all star. The all stars in my group were the ones that were  good at golfing and knew how to suck up to clients and partners. Everything else didn’t really mattered. Your performance is mainly based on the impression you left. 
- A lot are expected of you, with literally nothing in return other than a thank you
- A lot of pressure from the National team to increase engagement margin

The new discussions on making you think about how you performed and how you can do it better is suppose to make you see things from different angles, but you the firm is also teaching you how to pick on yourself.  The firm always expects perfection.  Big new flash, nobody is perfect! People are not robots.

headline: Typical Big4 Workplace
pros:
+ Young professional crowd.
+ Open to new ways of doing things.
+ Fairly flat structure - partners very approachable (mostly)
+ Big 4 recognition.
+ Interesting work with good levels of technical depth.
cons:
- Ridiculous systems and policies - creates significant administrative burden on practice staff.
- Pay rises mostly occur on promotion (otherwise enjoy your sub-cpi increase).
- Toxic culture perpetuated by firm policies. Very cliquey (your either in or your out, lots of private chat groups). This is exacerbated by hot desking.
- Focus only on billable targets. So advice to people: getting large clients with good recovery, drop small clients.
- Everything is perception based rather than impact based. Getting noticed is worth more than anything else.
- Unless you are an extrovert - it's a difficult environment.
- Due to focus on billables/revenue and hot desking: there is a lack of team culture (unless you have your own clique to hang out with) and lack of incentive to train junior staff and mentor.

headline: Great place to build your career
pros: PwC offers a great career platform and opportunities to work for top clients across all industries across the world. Hard work is encouraged and rewarded. This place is for go-getters and not for someone who wants a 9-5 job doing same things all over again.
cons: Work life balance is often compromised due to client demands and nature of the work. PwC however encourages people to take time off by offering a generous vacation package.

Like any big-4 firm, if you work for people who are just out for themselves, it's a miserable job.  Can't beat having PwC on your resume and you will learn a great deal.
cons:
You will pay your dues - lots of hours - and limited opportunities to arrange your schedule, especially early in your career.

headline: Great place to develop your career
pros: Best reason to work here is to get a great start on your career and learn a whole lot in a short period of time. There is a great wealth of knowledge sharing and the ability to use the resources is high. I have been able to progress through the firm with a relatively good pace and gain a lot of valuable exposure to complex issues that have benefited by learning. This is a fast paced environment and there are a large number of opportunities for someone to get involved in a variety of projects. There is also possibility for someone to branch out into other areas of the business and gain exposure in a new skill.
cons: One of the biggest down sides of working here is the lack of respect for personal work life balance. The high pressure of deadline driven business does not allow for a possibility to be flexible with your own time. As mentioned above there is lots of possibility to grow and develop but it definitely comes at a price of sacrificing personal time and work life balance. The compensation for time spent on clients is also not equivalent to the amount of hours dedicated to the firm and the sacrifices that are made for the Company. The pressure senior management puts on its staff is not always appreciated but rather demanded.

headline: I've learned a lot, but I've made sacrifices to do so
pros: Get to work with some of the largest companies in Pittsburgh, learn a lot, and develop a strong network of people your age.  There's a fairly linear track to promotions so you can project your career path at the firm fairly easily.  People who have left the firm, have done very well for themselves because of the great work experience.
cons: Due to tougher regulations, external reviews and a large new client, there has been a major staffing crunch in the last year.  This has led to more hours, higher expectations, and in turn more stress.  I think the partners are trying to fix this but it is tough to address in the short term.  Sometimes good people can act out a bit due to the stress.

headline: PwC is the place to be!
pros: During my internship, I learned so much about the advisory practice, as well as about PwC's corporate culture.  I was able to contribute to meaningful assignments and see how applicable my accounting degree is in the real-world.  I enjoyed applying my critical thinking skills and my accounting background to real-life tasks and projects.  In addition to the work opportunities I experienced at PwC, I also had a chance to meet the many people that build PwC's culture through various other networks, such as affinity groups and Toastmasters.  Overall, I have been thrilled with my internship, and I could not have asked for a more fulfilling and valuable experience.  This experience has been the perfect supplement to enhance my classroom education.
cons: I really did not hit any downsides during my nine week internship.  I was assigned to challenging, meaningful projects, and everyone really made me feel part of the PwC team.  Everyone at the office is very ambitious, so they definitely work hard-- but they know how to play hard too.  They hosted numerous social activities, where you can see your co-workers outside of the work environment-- events such as bowling, baseball games, wine tasting, etc.

headline: Working at PwC
pros: Great opportunity to meet different people with various experiences. For the most part, people are hard working. Due to working long hours, there is a flexibility in schedule available.
cons: Not enough resources. if you don't work directly with a partner or manager, you don't grow and no coaching. It can get tiring after while.The engagements you are on can make a significant difference. Some are good some are awful. The best are selected based on who they work for and how well trained they are. I have met some best rated people that are truly exceptional, but the firm invests in them and then I meet people with potential but are not even given the opportunity.

headline: Unprofessional when you leave for a competitor
pros: Fellow staff are extremely fun to be around; there's a real sense of community at the associate/senior associate level.
cons: Management does not care about the staff. I tried to make a switch from audit to consulting and they wouldn't let me. I wasn't offended, but I ended up taking a consulting job elsewhere. When I submitted my two-week notice, the Partners and the HR representative for my practice, berated me. They told me I was making a big mistake and to never ask anyone at PwC for a letter of recommendation. They also accused me of lying when I explained that I wanted to transfer within PwC but was told that wouldn't happen for multiple years.

headline: Assurance
pros: Your experience depends on the market you serve, management on your engagement team, and the client. The management and culture of the engagement tends to mirror that of the client, and fortunately, I was on a very well-managed team that allowed for greater work-life balance than most engagements. The firm overall has great benefits (medical, dental, vision, corporate perks, time off), but if you're not on a good team, than you could be stuck working 24/7 with no respite.
cons: Pay in the public accounting is a lot less than you'd think. The pay raises do tend to be better incrementally, but the base pay is usually so much lower that the incremental raises not at all substantial. Also, again, depending on the engagement, the work-life balance may be non-existent.

headline: pwc advisory: old school consulting experience
pros: good place to start and gain experience. maybe. it depends on the kind of experience that one seeks.  globally recognized brand and that may enhance one's resume. maybe. the other big consulting firms likely offer a richer and more enjoyable consulting career -especially, if interested in tech work.
cons: pwc is not an innovative place to work. not creative. likely because of assurance and tax practices, the culture's risk averse and conservative. it's the kind of place where a leader said to me, "we've done like this for 100+ years, so it must be working." this conservative attitude stifles creativity. pay is average. like typical consulting firm, it's all about being chargeable. if your on the bench for any period of time, watch out, there's probably a target on you and you may be on the way out. lots of competition, stress and pressure to be billable. not a fun place to work. despite pretenses,  it's all about work -no fun. pwc sucks the life from one. given the tax/assurance environment, not sure pwc can be different. glad to be out of there. it seems to work for some.

headline: Damaging corporate culture
pros:
Network is huge.
Training opportunities are excellent - you can train as much as you like and the content is brilliant. You can pretty much learn anything and often can travel to cool places to partake in training events.
 Opportunities when you leave are excellent.
cons: Had to endure and watch others endure harassment, sexism and in general, a terrible corporate culture. Partners don't care about their teams and will book you on anything/everything - regardless of skill set alignment, travel requirements, or insane client demands. Environment is hostile and competitive. Worst years of my life working here and I wouldn't recommend a job at PwC to anyone. Also important to note - men in my team were consistently paid more than women (e.g. 20k difference when the male had lower level of education and performace rating).

- They lost so many people in the downturn that the workload for the remaining people is intense.
- Compensation the last few years has been incredibly low relative to the expectations placed on the staff.

headline: Breadth of technical development, but cookie-cutter corporate culture is not friendly to creativity

headline: Its a great place to work (most of the time).

cons: The hours are long for everyone from January through March and can vary greatly beyond that time frame.  Also, travel can be a really bad part of this job for some people. Sometimes, you can be assigned to smaller clients and feel like you are alone on an island.

headline: Resume Builder but be careful to stand up for ethics
pros: At PwC you will build your resume, grow your professional network and most importantly grow your skillset faster than most of your peer group. You'll have exposure you can not get anywhere else outside of the big 4. You are surrounded by resources for learning and grown; if you get on a good team, with passionate seniors and managers, you'll be set up for many years.
cons: You can and will be thrown under the bus by managers and seniors if it benefits them. Although all the good things you hear about the big 4 are true, the bad are as well. Personally I was discriminated against for being LGBT; I spoke to HR and filed an ethics complaint only to be told to get over it. The result was, long term my, career at PwC was limited. Be careful when you speak up in the souther offices; the main firm policy may be inclusion, but the actual practice varies from office to office. It's sad, but our southern offices are still not as progressive as the rest of the firm.

headline: Don't be fooled; the work is mundane
pros:
Teaches you good professional habits for recent college graduates
Looks good on your resume
Dumb people in your social circle will think you work for an investment bank
cons:
Within their consulting division, they portray their projects as super important, smart, and strategic.  The reality is that those projects are in the minority.  The firm's bread and butter is in audit and tax.  The majority of the projects are large, terribly boring 'asset management' type activities no one wants to do.  You might get on a few good projects here and there, but for the most part, you won't like a majority of the projects.  PwC would rather take a boring 'dumb' project over a 'smart strategic' one 9 times out of 10.  Less risk and looks better in the partner's profolio.

PwC is great if you're a straight up accountant who loves long hours but doesn't necessary need to think too hard.  If you're more specialized, you don't have much of a future.  The work skews to the accounts, so they have more resources (entry level college grads), they win more work, and they advance up the pyramid scheme faster than consultants.

Also, PwC is highly siloed.  Transfering to another line of work within the firm will literally take years.  They will say 'oh you can do whatever you want.'  You can't.  If you're profitable, partners won't let you leave without long notice.  Any sane person would just go to another company and take you 15% raise.

headline: A Great Place to Work
pros: Lots of opportunities to advance your career exist at the firm. You are definitely put on the fast track at PwC, and get exposure to many many different organizations. Even if you're not a partner candidate, you can still gain a tremendous amount of exposure to various skills and organizations (though I wouldn't vocally express a disinterest in the partnership). Having PwC on your resume is like having a silver plating, and gets you a lot of credibility in the marketplace. The Firm does support it's staff, and appears to have an interest in their well being. There's lots of metrics to manage (particularly at the higher levels) but that could also be seen as a con.
cons: Lots of opportunities to advance your career exist at the firm. You are definitely put on the fast track at PwC, and get exposure to many many different organizations. Even if you're not a partner candidate, you can still gain a tremendous amount of exposure to various skills and organizations (though I wouldn't vocally express a disinterest in the partnership). headline: Brilliant people, great work and Clients, highly political environment conformity and old boy networks prevail

cons: political and cut-throat especially at the senior levels of the Firm.  Can be unjustly judged for being an individual and not being a robotic look alike.  A very "don't make waves" environment where one can be promoted by simply hanging in long enough, kissing the right anatomy of senior management, and consistently being a C.  Not the kind of place where one can risk being different or taking the chance of making a mistake.

headline: Good Money Early On
pros: The best reason to work for PwC is for the experience. As an intern you are exposed to a range of training and other enriching opportunities. It is a very good resume building experience. However, like most big businesses, there are politics invloved in regards to getting promoted further down the road. And busy season is how it is stated...busy. All the people that you work with are very compentant, I have not met anyone annoying. Many young people work here so it is cool.
cons: The workload, how unpredicatable it can be.  How it is such a large organization it is easy to feel lost.

headline: Great experience, especially out of college
pros: Great people who really are interested in your professional growth. There are many perks including flexibility and office outings. When you network within the firm, you can find people who can help you find your perfect fit within the firm.

headline: Nice place to settle down

headline: Good place to start your career
pros:
- Wide scope of work and range of clients. If you work really hard and prove your worth, there are a lot of great opportunities. If you put in the hard work, you can become an expert in the area that you choose to specialize in. 
- A lot of good people although as always in Big 4 many friends will leave in a few years 
- Good name on your resume
- working in the PwC network gives your lots of international exposure from the type of clients / work you do and with secondment opportunities
cons:
These comments apply to the Singapore firm 
- Dysfunctional office politics in the Singapore firm, especially in the past few years
- No work life balance for people who actually do work 
- Some teams in the Singapore firm tend to recognize people who can jockey their way up through politicking, but are not good team players (take credit from other's work) and are not technically strong in their area of specialization (which is bad for business because clients engage Big 4 for subject matter experts) 
- Insufficient onboarding and opportunities for mid-streamers and secondees. In some teams no real-time honest feedback are provided so many staff end up being underutilized. "Stars" are overloaded with work which is not sustainable

headline: Average.
pros: Depends on clients. If you get a good client, work will be very smooth, but if you are allotted a bad one, things can go the way you don't like
cons:
Hectic life. Not so friendly atmosphere. Regionalism.
Compensation is poor, perhaps lowest in the industry. Requires a lot of travel

headline: Senior Auditor
pros: Great Training, Family mentoring structure and amazing international opportunities
cons: Perception is everything in public accounting, a lot of politics

headline: Associate Director

cons: Notorious for not paying bonuses and lower salary than market. Can be some very tight deadlines and long hours if needed.

headline: Good fundamentals
pros: You quickly gain responsibility and see a variety of business processes and cliens. This position teaches you the fundamentals of business. It is a young and fun environment.
cons: Extremely structured and rigid career progression. You do not get much input on the clients you work on and can often be long hours.

headline: pwc

headline: Good place to work, but expect to work long hours.
pros: Opportunities abound at PwC if you look in the right places.  For the most part, raises have been fair, meaning they've met my expectations or exceeded them.  The Company is doing its best to balance the needs of its clients as well as its employees.  The professional feel of the offices is standard across cities and countries.  Of all the Big 4, I believe that PwC is doing the best in terms of treating its employees right (although ever group is a little bit different).
cons: The leverage model is inverted, meaning the higher you rise in the Company, the more you are expected to give in terms of time and effort.  Although you are awarded financially, the opportunity cost is having a life outside of PwC.

headline: Big4 is a BigTrap
pros: Onboarding and training programs are good. But I guess those are made to make you feel good for really bad times ahead.
cons:
- Too much favoritism - If you blindly agree to each and everything your boss says without any complaint, then this is the best place to work. But you have to sell your soul, your family time and your health.
- Work life balance is the worst and you don't get paid enough. 
- Limited and non transferable skills - You do quantitative, manual work and become obsolete. The more time you spend with these firm, the more it becomes difficult for you to move out.

headline: Assistant manager at Transaction Services
pros: I worked in the TS department which by many inside PwC was considered a harsher work environment. Because you see many companies and make indepth analyses there is a steep learning curve which I thought was very fun. Also the work environment with a lot of young motivated employees was very nice.
cons: The pay was low compared to market rates (had a 50% increase following my switch to industry) while the secondary benefits were heavily cut during the downturn. Internal partner politics can be tiring with each partner managing their own P&L.

headline: Do not work here
pros: Cant think of any pros.
cons: The company has a bad culture. The partners are oppressive.

headline: Client work is great, but work life balance does not exist
pros: The different clients typically are receptive to your ideas and thoughts, which provides a bit of satisfaction.  Pay is not too bad either, when looked at strictly from a salary perspective (looking at hourly will put a dent in the pay opinion however)
cons: The constant work load, long nights, early morning, and never ending stress of always having more and more pushed upon you to do make for an overall experience that I could not envision maintaining for an entire career.

cons:

– Career coaching is practically non-existent due to focus on clients and not really caring about junior staff career development

headline: Work is only as good as your local practice
pros: PwC is a huge company that offers diverse opportunities across the country. For example, I was able to transfer from the Philadelphia office to the McLean office with no problem. Work cultures are different in every office. Pay scales are as competitive as could be imagined for accounting, and most employees beyond the associate level are company men who seek that reliable salary.
cons: The second edge of the sword of PwC's culture is that your colleagues will likely not be worldly or interested in affairs other than making money in their practices. "Global acumen" is at a minimum. This is accounting, after all. Some groups and office treasure diversity and learning, while others keep their heads down to they can see an ever-increasing salary. That's the "other second" edge - raises are tantalizing high, so there is always the illusion of great economic benefit even if salaries are low. I had never seen a raise smaller than 14% in my four years.

cons: There's less focus on delivering strong technical consulting (e.g. cloud security architecture, embedding devsecops, threat modeling, etc.) and more push to continue doing the traditional 'maturity assessment' which is leaving the team behind the curve as the rest of the big 4 push ahead.

headline: Great People, but Leadership needs to fix things
pros: Some great people you get to work with, some great clients as well.
cons:
As you get higher up in the firm, the people above you give you less support and direction, but they will put you on projects you have no idea how to do with no guidance. After senior associate, they promote who kisses up the most or who gives up their life rather than who deserves it based on merit and work product. 
They promote diversity and inclusion, but when you look at the leaders of the firm there's barely any diversity/inclusion in the people who stay at the firm longterm.

headline: Just learned a most valuable lesson...there's simply no loyalty in companies anymore
pros: You get to claim you worked for a company that has been voted as 100 Best Companies to work for.
cons:
PwC massively laid off a bunch of their resources yet again! The same people that implemented the "inefficient" IT organization structure from the last time they had a massive layoff from 2010 are still in place and all the worker bees paid the price for it. 

I agree that the business model of third party matrix model was an absolute ridiculousness...it was so inefficient! It required a lot of red tape on "approvals" and overtime just to make it work.  However, don't blame the worker bees, including the managers that tried managing that, blame the "leadership" that came up with that, who are by the way are still there!

They claimed that they've tried matching resources in roles, whoever "they" are because our direct supervisors were not even consulted when they were matching roles.  They've claimed that they've merged roles, but it was clear that it was bottom-line cutting after realizing who were let go.  They got rid of people that were with the firm for a long period of time, earned a lot and/or manager/senior manager/director levels.  Some who were even almost near retirement!  If you look at the career site, you'll find roles that they could have easily matched with more than a handful of people that they got rid of.

Not exactly sure how this company got the "100 Best Company to work for" when in reality they failed to take care of their employees.  They could have tried harder in taking care of the very people that worked and served for 10-25+ yrs! They could have given them the option to take on a lower level or looked at their overall experiences and offered education in topics, e.g. DevOps, Agile, etc.  Instead, they've chosen to let go nearly 400 people from Finance, Marketing & Sales, HR and IT.

If you are looking to work here, plan on getting it in your mind that this is NOT the company to grow roots.  Learn whatever there is to learn and move on to other companies that actually care.

headline: Unimpressive middle management
pros: It is a big company, with lots of smart young people. If you want to move to a different city, or even country, its likely that you could just transfer to a different office. Their national and global network is really great.
cons:
Middle management is very poor. The hours are long and work-life balance is pretty non-existent, so many people leave before they get promoted to a managerial position.  The managers are not the  people who are the best fit for the position, but  just who have stuck around long enough to make their way up the corporate ladder. This has a very strong negative effect on team dynamics and projects.

Also, in terms of salary, they do a very poor job of compensating for cost of living. I happened to be in San Francisco, the most expensive city in the country, and I know that I was making the same as people who started  in states like Florida, where cost of living is substantially lower. Also, in comparison to other Big Four accounting firms, it appeared to be quite a bit lower.

Greater emphasis is put on getting the work done than specific hours that one works which allows for flexibility for people who need it.  PwC is very concerned with maintaining a work-life balance, so employees are given extra days off during various holidays during the year as well as floating holidays and 22 vacation days.  People regularly took two week vacations.
cons: There is office politics at play as usual, but as this is the case at just about any large organization it is not particularly newsworthy other than the fact that you had better hitch your wagon to a rising star rather than a waning one if you can help it.

headline: Good, stable place to begin a career.
pros: PwC, just like most accounting firms, offers a stability above all other things. All in all it is a great firm, as far as culture goes. There are many opportunities to advance but you have to like working a lot doing tedious and unexciting tasks for many many hours. If you thrive in a small fish big pond atmosphere then you will do well here. It is a young firm which makes it a good place for an entry level candidate.
cons: The work is tedious and unexciting and often times I asked myself if I were adding any true value. As with any large corporate culture office politics came in to play sometimes.

headline: Good place to start a career
pros:
You'll gain a really good baseline of professionalism - time management, client interaction, presentations, note-taking, 'managing up', how to learn quickly, quality work quality, etc.

There's also VAST amount of learning resources - you can find training on a variety of different technologies, expertises, etc.

The pay isn't so bad either, especially if you're traveling as you can basically expense your living (sans rent) for four days a week.
cons:
They preach work-life balance by emphasizing that you shouldn't be working too long on client engagements...but then expect you to contribute 1-5 hours per day on 'reinvest' work. Business dev, internal stuff, thought leadership...in many sense they expect you to pick up a part-time job on top of your full-time job

As with any large corporation, you begin to feel like just a number and that you're contributing work to a huge, vast enterprise and you can't see your impact. It's really hard to get promoted unless your a total type A and on top of everything / willing to sell your soul to it.

headline: Great Company, Opportunity for Advancement, Long Hours and Low Pay
pros: PwC has a fantastic internal network of experts to leverage knowledge from.  The benefits (vacation, holiday, cell phones) are well above that of working in industry.  Learning and professional growth opportunities are never-ending, and there is always room for promotions and advancement.
cons: It's a client service company - lots of long hours, unreasonable deadlines, no overtime pay, and very little work/life balance.  With the current economy, there were no raises or bonuses in 2008, and moral is extremely low.  Many people work for the company and overlook the long hours due to the higher pay rate, but most public accountants actually make less than their counterparts in industry/corporate positions until they are promoted to director, which could take in excess of ten years.

headline: Life at PwC
pros:
Great network - Pwc is very huge in India and hence you will definitely find a former Pwc employee at any organisation making it very easy to network

cons: The culture is similar to a government organisation where in seniority matters more than merit

headline: PwC - recommend
pros:
- inclusive and friendly culture
- people are honest, nice and hard-working

cons:

- network model means no real global integration, more like different local satellites working in silos

headline: Intrapreneurial mindset required
pros:
PwC does it ALL. We have strategy consulting, agency capabilities, dev resources, designers, deployment capabilities globally, and so on. There is really not much that PwC doesn't do. So there is opportunity to be had in this environment if you have some idea as to what you want to do and are able to network into the teams that do this type of work. 

You may not win on every project but you are able to get a pretty good batting average and then over time build up the relationship capital to be able to get where you want to go. There is a lot of opportunity for career pivots within the firm so before leaving to get your MBA, I always recommend that people first use the firm as a testing ground to see if they like the proposed area and then build a nice story for your application by demonstrating how you are already starting to move your career in this direction.

We continue to add in new capabilities continuously and there is great opportunity to actually start doing work that in industry you probably wouldn't be given the chance to do because you didn't have the experience yet. I firmly believe that PwC offers a great development opportunity for folks who aren't quite sure "what they want to be when they grow up" as you can continue to test careers without committing while gaining great experience along the way.
cons:
PwC does it ALL. There is a downside to this as well. We are amazingly large now and figuring out who does exactly what you are interested in doing is kind of like the six degrees of separation game with Kevin Bacon. There is a lot of organizational inefficiency to get to where you want to go, and this includes the client delivery side as well. You could be working on an engagement struggling along and then realize some team three doors down is working on the same exact project for another client. You network not just because it's the culture but also because it is a survival skill. 

The net result is that it takes a while to get the relationship capital and organizational understanding together to really know what the opportunities are and then at that point we tend to have lost folks because they feel like they are a ship afloat at sea without a paddle. You really need to work to find the superconnectors to minimize the degrees of separation to enable you to really take charge of your career.

headline: PWC The Big 4 experience
pros: PWC is one of the "Big 4" accounting firms and provides all of their employess with excellent salaries, benefits and challenges. The Chicago office is large, but since i spend most of my time out on audits, I don't spend much time there. I feel like I am surrounded by an educated and qualified staff. The work week is manageable and the vacation time is adequate even in the first few years of employment. I am overall glad that I accepted a position with PWC. The years that I will spend with this company will open the doors to many other firms and corporate work in the future.
cons:
Work Place Climate
One of the biggest downsides of working out of Chicago office is that there is a very cutthroat attitude among many of the associates. As with any business that operates under a partnership, rivalries arrise. The partners tend to gravitate towards their own circles and create a work climate that can be intimidating at times. 

Audit Audit Audit
My first couple of years were spent on audits which is not exactly the most titilating work. I would reccomend that you know exactly what type of accounting you would like to get into to before you accept a job with a large accounting firm.

headline: Gain experience through a lot of work
pros: Every year that you work here (as with other public accounting firms) as worth 3-5 years of work in the private sector. For example my client has an accounting manager that has been internally promoted. It took her 25 years to reach her current position. Her bosses boss, the controller, worked in public accounting for 8 years and makes ~$40k more a year.
cons: You will not have a life. Even weeks that are not busy season are 55-60 hour work weeks. If you aren't on a client then you will probably be traveling to do an inventory observation. Don't get too excited about that, because there's only so much you can do in Yuma, AZ, Monte Vista, CO, or Burley, ID on a Tuesday or Wednesday night. Also, even if one of those days is a travel day, you will be expected to work on the plane in order to make "efficient use of your time" and not fall behind.

headline: Review For PwC India Kolkata
pros:
1. Good pay only to people from premier colleges and lateral hires
2. Good hike
3. Reimbursement for certifications
cons:
1. Very poor work-life balance
2. Discrimination between employees from premier colleges and other colleges (even during appraisal and performance moderation)
3. Very weak HR department (toothless tigers wagging their tails)
4. Working for multiple clients as a full-time resource at the same time even without the Client's knowledge which is unethical and it takes a toll on employee's mental and physical health. (Been there done that).
5. Release from projects or switching between projects even after working on the same projects for 4 - 5 years is not encouraged/ not allowed to an extent. If you do Directors would hold grudge against you.
6. No check on Directors/ Partners no matter how unethical the work environment under them becomes to meet Engagement Margin

headline: Boston Advisory Practice

cons: If you plan to work in advisory, do not believe any promises during the hiring process regarding not having to travel. Even if that is a communicated preference, it will be ignored as the location of the work will dictate whether you travel.

headline: Good place to train broad set of management skills with focus on leading international complicate project
pros:
There are quite broad options and opportunities to select mostly fit area of business and industry for any set of initial competencies and knowledge.
Good place to test own capability to innovate and to unleash own initiatives.
Good place to seek opportunities of international secondment.
Quite good place to acquire new knowledge.
Good place to know and to understand broadly supported and recognised world wide trends  in economy and business approaches.
cons:
There are mostly conventional approaches in management despite loud declaring edge technology and flexibility to try new approaches (may be it is consequence of the scale and slow changeable partnership structure).
Many flexible forms of structuring projects are constrained or limited by highly strong and complicated risk management (OGC dep) due to audit branch of the firm requires extremely constrained frame of work for any other branches of the brand.
Career focus exceeds professional focus and professional development in most cases amid middle and top management (Russia and Kazakhstan offices were observed only)

headline: Join if you plan to stay here for more than 10 years.

cons:
-Salary is way lower in proportion to the amount of work demanded.
-Zero work-life balance.
-A few managers are extremely authoritative and controlling.Family based culture. Loyalty to the family matters more than your performance on the job.
-A strict no-go for freshers as there is no technical training program and learning is on the job( you are expected to learn it from the family :P:P).
-Arbitrary and random allocation of projects to resources disregarding their core competencies.
-Late hours work. No added incentives.
-Managers expect you to share your personal life with them as well. No clear demarcation of personal and professional life. They expect you to spend the rest of your life here.

headline: I work is Risk Assurance performing IT audit and controls testing (primarily SOX and third party assurance).
pros: The experience is great. I learn a lot every day. I get to travel internationally. I get to work with driven and intelligent coworkers. PwC has good training programs that help us develop. PwC is a big Firm so there are a variety of jobs and experience you can gain, in a variety of different places.
cons: There seems to always be more work than there are staff to perform it. Turnover is high, which makes it difficult to improve the work environment. Demands can be unreasonable. The culture at PwC encourages focusing more and more at work, at the expense of personal health, family, and other priorities. Some of the people you report to can be very difficult to work with because of this cut throat culture.

headline: Consulting
pros: Great group of people at this firm. Consulting has a reputation of having egocentric people however, I didn't have that experience at PwC... Most people were fantastic to work with but you still have to "keep up appearances" so no surprises there. I enjoyed my time there and the projects I worked on were challenging and rewarding. It takes some networking to find the right projects but once you do it is a great experience in learning.
cons:
Consulting is a very unique career and anyone who chooses this career field should be prepared for the challenges it comes with.
With that said PwC itself has gone through some changes after the acquisition of Strategy& and getting a project is much harder than it used to be with all the mouths to feed now. 

The whole management process is also a bit messy as one does not have a traditional manager who is heavily invested in your career - some consulting companies are better at this than others at managing this problem and PwC is not one of the good ones. It can feel like you are on an Island most of the time.

headline: A fantastic place to work
pros:
- Arguably the most people focussed and collegiate culture of all the Big 4. Very friendly colleagues and there is a focus on projects to create a great experience for individuals, team and client
- Focus on delivery and not face-time - trusted to work how you want
- Leadership are always striving to further improve the PwC experience for staff
- Work with very talented, driven and supportive colleagues
- Diverse and young - lots of energy and social opportunity
- Best of the best clients with lots of opportunities for international travel if desired
- Available training is second to none. However, training focuses much more on soft / consulting skills than technical
- Promotion can be quick if you demonstrate the required attributes
cons:
- There can be quite a heavy emphasis on internal contributions (e.g. practice development, career coaching, thought leadership etc) on top of day to day client work . This is often required to hit top performance ratings given there'll always be colleagues to do this.
- There can be a lot of beaurocracy and compliance matters to attend to (e.g. rigorous year end and promotion processes, lots of risk and quality procedures to follow etc) which over time can become tiresome.
- Recently my part of the firm has been running at low capacity and are not recruiting fast enough - this has limited choice of engagements in recent periods
- Significant pay increases tend (though not exclusively) to be on promotion. The firm could be better at within grade pay-rises and moving high performers up the pay bands.

cons: Increasing workload, stress and over time

headline: Tax - International Assignment Services
pros: Overall good company to work for.  The best aspect is the investment they make in you.  You will have ample amounts of training both in the classroom and on-the-job.  Bonuses are offered for getting your credentials  (i.e. CPA, EA, etc) and company covers the cost of training materials.  The work is challenging and there are plenty of opportunities for advancement.  Office atmosphere is relatively relaxed in the off-season.  Pay and benefits are satisfactory and in-line with the market.  Will do what they can to make you happy so you remain with the company - plenty of other internal job opportunities.  Can work remotely when needed.
cons: You will WORK.  They often preach work / life balance at the top, but it rarely flows to middle and lower management.  Staff may leave and not be replaced without any change in the amount of work resulting in existing employees taking on additional assignments.  More compliance work is being transferred overseas.  Busy-season can get stressful and you will see your co-workers more than family.  Office politics can influence management decisions (fairly common in the workplace).

headline: Great Place
pros:
- The sky is the limit.  It is an "up or out" mentality and they bend over backwards to make sure it is mostly up, rather than out.
- Training opportunities. It is an incredible place to start your career in the business world.  Sets you up for a guaranteed successful future, whether you end up here long term or move your talents elsewhere.
- Pay starts out just okay, but once you hit manager in 4-5 years, the pay is more than good and raises every year are pretty amazing.  Not too difficult to get both a 10% raise and 10% bonus every single year.
- Flexibility.  Sure you work long hours some time, but you have plenty of opportunities to take off early or work from home.
cons: =- trying to hit enough chargeable hours while also staying on budget

pros:
-vibe: great people if you are lucky like me, most of my supervisors are very understanding and caring. They don't force you to do things you don't feel comfortable doing, and they are all also very reasonable
-location: Shanghai office is in the most prime location, and it has great access to a lot of things
-flexible time: at least in RA there are no required time for you to get there, though it is recommended to get in before 10am (but if you pulled an all nighter or had a long day beforehand, some managers always understand if you get in a little late)
-project flexibility: depends on the team, you get different projects, and the difficulty of the projects vary from one to another; sometimes you get to pick, other times you don't
-flexible reporting structure: my team didn't really have a hierarchy, we are free to discuss or report to ranging from senior associates to senior managers.
cons:
-super long working hours
-low paygrade
-slow expense process

headline: Study + On the job experience + tight deadline + burnt weekends + fast pay progress
pros: You are placed in a pressure cooker environment during peak periods where you are rushing to meet deadlines. Learning is normally on the job and care must be taken to self learn as much as possible as limited coaching is available during jobs as seniors are stressed up themselves.
cons:
Not worth the money for the hours spent.
Deal with difficult clients.
Deal with difficult TICs and Managers.

headline: Only a good place to work if you are die-hard about accounting and/or taxation...
pros: PWC has a good entry-level salary and internship program. Depending on which sector of their Tax, Audit, or Advisory sector you are placed in will basically provide a different experience for each employee.
cons: During a busy season the morale is generally low due to everyone working extremely long hours (80-100 hours/week, including weekends). Many "senior" associates have little or no knowledge or competence in the work they do and waste the time of everyone working on the project. The concepts and office environment is manipulated by HR which basically markets a bunch of lies such as "work/life balance". Unless you are head over heels about the accounting profession and are ready to make balance sheets something you eat, breathe, and live...look elsewhere.

headline: bait and switch approach to recruiting
pros: =- staying in nice, expensive Hotels Once in a while.
cons:
- Basically the job was not as nice as advertised in the beginning and I ended up writing SQL queries which was not part of what I signed up for.
- I did not meet any of the team I had to work with.
- Three dudes who interviewed me (whom I liked) were not my managers in the end.
- Not good pay for an IT guy in the first 2-3 years.

Management is very supportive and will do anything to help you. I really enjoyed my time here and would do it all over again. The perks of this job are absolutely amazing. Flexible schedule, great benefits and much, much more! If you have the opportunity, work here!

headline: I like working at PWC.
pros: My partner and manager gave me space to finish my work. Sometimes I needed to work overtime but I got reasonable paid. The company cares about employee education. We always had parties after every busy season.
cons: There were always not enough team member and there were always a lot of work to do. Because of that, I learned to use time effectively.
